Uses .remove which is not native js supported in IE9 or lower */\n\t\t/*if('querySelector' in document\n\t\t&& 'localStorage' in window\n\t\t&& 'addEventListener' in window)*/\n\t\t\n\t\t/* This is the updated selector, taken from: https://justmarkup.com/log/2015/02/26/cut-the-mustard-revisited/ */\n\t\tif('visibilityState' in document) {\n\t\t\n\t\t/*! loadJS: load a JS. We are loading this command straight away, before the body loads, so that IF a user has JS enabled, their show hide panels will automatically be closed. */\n\t\t/* If this isn't here, then these panels appear open while the page is loading, then when the js loads at the bottom of the page, they are shut. So the users sees open content, then hidden after a second or 2 when the js is loaded. Not nice */\n\t\tdocument.write(\"<style>.reveal-content{display:none;}.search-res-filter .reveal-content{display:block;}</style>\");\n\t\t}\n\t\t</script>\n\t\t<script>var __uzdbm_1 = \"8211a71a-786b-41c8-93ad-0fd33bfd5180\";var __uzdbm_2 = \"YWYzNWRjMzYtODQyNy00YzZiLTk5ODYtMWJiNjUwOTg1NDZjJDE1NS4xMDEuMjYuMTEx\";</script> <script>(function(w, d, e, u, c, g, a, b){ w[\"SSJSConnectorObj\"] = {ss_cid : c, domain_info: \"auto\"}; a = d.createElement(e); a.async = true; a.src = u; b = d.getElementsByTagName(e)[0]; b.parentNode.insertBefore(a, b); })(window,document,\"script\",\"https://cdn.perfdrive.com/aperture/aperture.js\",\"a1c3\",\"ssConf\");</script></head>\n\t<body itemscope itemtype=\"http://schema.org/Organization\" class=\"issn-0004-637X\">\n    <a id=\"back-to-top-target\" tabindex=\"-1\"></a>\n    <!-- Google Tag Manager (noscript) -->\n<noscript><iframe src=\"https://www.googletagmanager.com/ns.html?id=GTM-M73Z4W\"\n    height=\"0\" width=\"0\" style=\"display:none;visibility:hidden\"></iframe></noscript>\n<!-- End Google Tag Manager (noscript) --><div class=\"cookies-banner-wrap\" id=\"cookieBanner\">\n    <div class=\"cookies-banner cf\">\n        This site uses cookies. <main role=\"main\">\n        <!-- Secondary header starts -->\n<div class=\"secondary-header cf\" id=\"wd-secondary-header\">\n    <!-- Branded journal header starts -->\n<div class=\"big-branded\">\n\n    <div class=\"publication-name\" id=\"wd-pub-name\">\n\t<div class=\"publication-title\" itemprop=\"name\" itemid=\"periodical\">\n\t\t\t\t<!-- Journal image link tile alt=\"The Astrophysical Journal\">\n</a>\n<!-- Logo tile ends -->\n<!-- Journal image link tile ends -->\n</div>\n\t\t</div>\n    <div class=\"partner-logos m-hide\" id=\"wd-partner-logos\">\n            <div class=\"partner-logo-alignment\">\n                <!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/8a2230b8-d09c-11e5-b0b6-759f86a2008e/aas-2018.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The American Astronomical Society, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The American Astronomical Society (AAS), established in 1899 and based in Washington, DC, is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America. Its membership of about 7,000 individuals also includes physicists, mathematicians, geologists, engineers, and others whose research and educational interests lie within the broad spectrum of subjects comprising contemporary astronomy. The mission of the AAS is to enhance and share humanity's scientific understanding of the universe.</p> <p><a href=\"https://aas.org/\">https://aas.org/</a></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<!-- Partner logo tile starts -->\n<a href=\"\" class=\"overlay-launch\">\n    <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n</a>\n<span class=\"overlay-set\">\n    <div class=\"tint-screen\"></div>\n    <div class=\"overlay-panel\">\n        <a title=\"Close\"  class=\"close-icon close-overlay\" tabindex=\"0\" role=\"button\" aria-describedby=\"close-icon-description\"><span class=\"icon-close\"></span></a>\n        <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.</p>\n        <div class=\"overlay-img\">\n            <a href=\"\">\n                <img border=\"0\" src=\"https://cms.iopscience.org/7ebd1b32-0439-11e9-b401-cfe9679c40e3/iop-2016.png?guest=true\" alt=\"The Institute of Physics, find out more\">\n            </a>\n        </div>\n        <div class=\"overlay-text\">\n            <p>The Institute of Physics (IOP) is a leading scientific society promoting physics and bringing physicists together for the benefit of all. It has a worldwide membership of around 50 000 comprising physicists from all sectors, as well as those with an interest in physics. It works to advance physics research, application and education; and engages with policy makers and the public to develop awareness and understanding of physics. Its publishing company, IOP Publishing, is a world leader in professional scientific communications.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.iop.org\">https://www.iop.org</a></p></div>\n        <p class=\"ta-c mt-1 mb-2\"><a href=\"\"></a></p>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- Partner logo tile ends -->\n\n<p></p>\n                </div>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n<!-- Branded journal header ends -->\n</div> <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F884%2F1%2F85\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/884/1/85</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>Large surveys of galaxy clusters with the <I>Hubble Space Telescope</I> (<I>HST</I>) and <I>Spitzer</I>, including the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble and the Frontier Fields, have demonstrated the power of strong gravitational lensing to efficiently deliver large samples of high-redshift galaxies. We extend this strategy through a wider, shallower survey named RELICS, the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey, described here. Our 188-orbit Hubble Treasury Program observed 41 clusters at 0.182\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<I>z</I>\u00a0\u2264\u00a00.972 with Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) and WFC3/IR imaging spanning 0.4\u20131.7 <I>\u03bc</I>m. We selected 21 of the most massive clusters known based on <I>Planck</I> PSZ2 estimates and 20 additional clusters based on observed or inferred lensing strength. RELICS observed 46 WFC3/IR pointings (~200 arcmin<SUP>2</SUP>) each with two orbits divided among four filters (F105W, F125W, F140W, and F160W) and ACS imaging as needed to achieve single-orbit depth in each of three filters (F435W, F606W, and F814W). As previously reported by Salmon et al., we discovered over 300 <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a06\u201310 candidates, including the brightest <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a06 candidates known, and the most distant spatially resolved lensed arc known at <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a010. <I>Spitzer</I> IRAC imaging (945 hr awarded, plus 100 archival, spanning 3.0\u20135.0 <I>\u03bc</I>m) has crucially enabled us to distinguish <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidates from <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a02 interlopers. For each cluster, two <I>HST</I> observing epochs were staggered by about a month, enabling us to discover 11 supernovae, including 3 lensed supernovae, which we followed up with 20 orbits from our program. Reduced <I>HST</I> images, catalogs, and lens models are available on MAST, and reduced <I>Spitzer</I> images are available on IRSA.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/884/1/85&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/884/1/85&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019ApJ...884...85C\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2019ApJ...884...85C&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2019ApJ...884...85C\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs1\" name=\"apjab412bs1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Gravitational lensing magnification by massive galaxy clusters has a long history of helping astronomers discover the most distant galaxies known with the <em>Hubble</em> <em>Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) and <em>Spitzer</em> (see Kneib &amp; Natarajan <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib98\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib98\">2011</a> Section 5.8 for a review). Twenty years ago, a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a04.92 galaxy lensed by the cluster MS 1358+62 was the most distant known (Franx et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib61\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib61\">1997</a>). Ten years ago, that record belonged to A1689-zD1 at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a07.5 (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib22\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib22\">2008</a>; Watson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib209\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib209\">2015</a>). More recently, the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (CLASH; Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>) yielded the triply imaged <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010.8 candidate MACS0647-JD (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>; Pirzkal et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib142\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib142\">2015</a>; Chan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib35\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib35\">2017</a>). This redshift has been surpassed only by the grism measurement of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a011.1 (Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib132\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib132\">2016</a>) for GN-z11 discovered by Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib130\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib130\">2014</a> in blank-field imaging by the CANDELS program (Grogin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib67\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib67\">2011</a>; Koekemoer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib100\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib100\">2011</a>). Both <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a011 galaxies are similarly bright at 1.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m (F160W AB mag 25.9), making them excellent targets for follow-up study with the <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> (<em>JWST</em>).</p><p>For a given observing strategy, lensed fields generally yield significantly more high-redshift galaxies than blank fields, especially at the highest redshifts and in relatively shallow imaging (e.g., Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>). Lensing does sacrifice high-redshift search volume owing to the magnification and the foreground cluster light. But lensing more than compensates for the lost volume by magnifying many more faint galaxies into view whenever luminosity function number counts are steeper than <em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>L</em><sup>\u22122</sup> (Broadhurst et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib28\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib28\">1995</a>). This is especially true brightward of <em>L</em>*, for example, AB mag ~28 at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a08 (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib23\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib23\">2012</a>; Finkelstein <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib58\">2016</a>).</p><p>CLASH demonstrated this lensing advantage, yielding significantly more galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20138 than blank-field surveys (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib24\">2014</a>). CLASH obtained 20-orbit <em>HST</em> imaging for each of 25 clusters in 16 filters, including F160W observed to AB mag 27.5 (5<em>\u03c3</em> depth; Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>; Molino et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib125\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib125\">2017</a>). The first 18 clusters yielded 262 candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20138 (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib24\">2014</a>), plus a few at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a09\u201311 (Zheng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib216\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib216\">2012</a>; Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>; Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib15\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib15\">2014</a>).</p><p>The Frontier Fields (Lotz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib107\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib107\">2017</a>) obtained deeper 140-orbit <em>HST</em> imaging for each of six clusters and six blank parallel fields in seven filters, including F160W observed to AB mag 28.7. At these depths, <em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>L</em><sup>\u22122</sup> for high-redshift galaxies (the luminosity function faint-end slope <em>\u03b1</em> ~ \u22122 roughly at <em>z</em> ~ 6 \u2212 8), so the lensed and blank-field high-<em>z</em> counts were predicted to be similar (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>). Indeed, the Frontier Fields yielded similar total numbers of lensed and blank-field high-redshift galaxies, altogether 453 at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20139 from one analysis (Kawamata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib93\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib93\">2018</a>), plus a few <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidates (Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib221\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib221\">2014</a>; Infante et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib81\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib81\">2015</a>; McLeod et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib120\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib120\">2016</a>; Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib131\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib131\">2018</a>). Due to their magnifications, the lensed galaxies are intrinsically fainter than the blank-field galaxies. By combining deep <em>HST</em> imaging with the power of gravitational lensing, the Frontier Fields revealed the faintest galaxies yet known, including some of those likely responsible for reionization at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06 (Livermore et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib106\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib106\">2017</a>; Atek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib8\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib8\">2018</a>).</p><p>While CLASH and the Frontier Fields yielded many high-redshift candidates, neither survey was optimized to deliver high-redshift candidates observed brightly enough for detailed follow-up study with current and future observatories. Detailed studies are required to determine galaxies' ages, stellar masses, compositions, and ionizing strengths (see Stark <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib188\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib188\">2016</a> for a review). This knowledge can further inform how early galaxies enriched and reionized the universe (see Dayal &amp; Ferrara <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib47\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib47\">2018</a> for a review). It is imperative to use existing facilities to discover the best targets for study, ideally before <em>JWST</em> Cycle 1. Gravitational lensing offers the most efficient route to do this. The <em>Planck</em> all-sky survey delivered the PSZ2 catalog of &gt;1000 massive galaxy clusters (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib145\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib145\">2016a</a>) detected via their Sunyaev\u2013Zel'dovich (SZ) effect (Sunyaev &amp; Zeldovich <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib194\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib194\">1970</a>) on the cosmic microwave background (CMB). By searching the PSZ2 catalog, we found that many massive clusters (including presumably excellent lenses) lacked the combination of <em>HST</em> Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) and Wide Field Camera 3 infrared (WFC3/IR) imaging required to discover high-redshift candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06.</p><p>RELICS embarked on an efficient survey with <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> to discover the best and brightest high-redshift galaxies (Coe <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib40\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib40\">2018</a>). RELICS obtained five-orbit <em>HST</em> imaging of 41 clusters in seven filters (the same filters used by the Frontier Fields), including F160W to AB mag 26.5. Our relatively shallow imaging covered more area than CLASH or the Frontier Fields, yielding high-redshift candidates that are brighter, either intrinsically and/or due to lensing magnification. See Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt1\">1</a> for a summary comparison of CLASH, the Frontier Fields, and RELICS. More recently, a new <em>HST</em> program, BUFFALO (PIs Steinhardt &amp; Jauzac; GO 15117), has begun, extending the Frontier Fields to the wider area covered by deep <em>Spitzer</em> imaging.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nRecent Large <em>HST</em> Cluster Lensing Surveys\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table Fields</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">RELICS</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Clusters</td>\n<td xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt1fna\">a</a></sup>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">188</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Supernova orbits<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a
