         <p id=\"close-icon-description\" class=\"offscreen-hidden\">\n                Click here to close this overlay, or press the \"Escape\" key on your keyboard.\n            </p>\n            <form id=\"alertsForm\" class=\"overlay-panel__form\" method=\"post\" action=\"\" role=\"form\" aria-labelledby=\"alerts-box-title\">\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__header\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__logo\"></div>\n                    <span id=\"alerts-box-title\" class=\"replica-h2\">Corridor alerts</span>\n                    <p id=\"alerts-box-desc\">\n                        Receive alerts on all new research papers in American Astronomical Society\n                        (<span class=\"abbr__aas\">A&nbsp;A&nbsp;S&nbsp;</span>) journals as soon as they are published.\n                        Select your desired journals and corridors below. You will need to select a minimum of one corridor.\n                    </p>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__container\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-corridors-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"corridors-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Corridors</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__col\">\n                        <fieldset id=\"alerts-journals-list\">\n                            <legend id=\"journals-title\" class=\"overlay-panel__heading replica-h3 mb-05\">Journals</legend>\n                        </fieldset>\n                    </div>\n                    <div class=\"boxout-bg-blue-light overlay-panel__extra-info\">\n                        <p>\n                            Please note, The Astrophysical Journal Letters (ApJL) and Research Notes of the AAS (RNAAS)\n                            do not currently use the corridors.\n                        </p>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n                <div class=\"overlay-panel__footer\">\n                    <div class=\"overlay-panel__inner-footer\">\n                        <input id=\"update-alerts\" type=\"submit\" value=\"Create alert\" class=\"btn btn-default overlay-panel__btn\" role=\"button\">\n                        <div class=\"icon-spinner spinner overlay-panel__loading\"></div>\n                    </div>\n                </div>\n            </form>\n        </div>\n    </div>\n</span>\n<!-- End TOC Subjects Popup -->\n            <p class=\"mb-0\"><a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert jnl-email-alert--corridors-info\" href=\"https://journals.aas.org/corridors.html\"\n               target=\"_blank\" title=\"Find out more about AAS corridors.\">\n                What are corridors? <span class=\"icon-newtab\">\n            </a></p>\n        </div>\n\n    <!-- End Email Alert -->\n<!-- End Email Alert --><!-- Start Citation Alert Link -->\n                        <p>\n<div class=\"jnl-notifications-wrapper\">\n    <a class=\"wd-jnl-email-alert\" href=\"https://myiopscience.iop.org/signin?origin=a0&return=https%3A%2F%2Fiopscience.iop.org%2Fmyiopscience%2Falerts%2Fsubscribe%3FarticleID%3D0004-637X%2F884%2F1%2F85\"><span\n            class=\"icon-alarm icon-alarm--jhp\"></span>Create citation alert</a>\n</div><!-- End Citation Alert Link -->\n                    </div>\n\t\t</div>\n    </div>\n    <!-- Article information ends -->\n<!-- Start Info top-->\n    <!-- end Info top --><div class=\"article-content\">\n\t<span id=\"articleId\" class=\"hide\">0004-637X/884/1/85</span>\n<!-- Start Abstract -->\n    <h2 id=\"artAbst\" class=\"collapse-blocked\">Abstract</h2>\n        <!-- Start article video abstract -->\n\t<!-- End article video abstract -->\n\t<div class=\"article-text wd-jnl-art-abstract cf\" itemprop=\"description\">\n             <P>Large surveys of galaxy clusters with the <I>Hubble Space Telescope</I> (<I>HST</I>) and <I>Spitzer</I>, including the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble and the Frontier Fields, have demonstrated the power of strong gravitational lensing to efficiently deliver large samples of high-redshift galaxies. We extend this strategy through a wider, shallower survey named RELICS, the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey, described here. Our 188-orbit Hubble Treasury Program observed 41 clusters at 0.182\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<I>z</I>\u00a0\u2264\u00a00.972 with Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) and WFC3/IR imaging spanning 0.4\u20131.7 <I>\u03bc</I>m. We selected 21 of the most massive clusters known based on <I>Planck</I> PSZ2 estimates and 20 additional clusters based on observed or inferred lensing strength. RELICS observed 46 WFC3/IR pointings (~200 arcmin<SUP>2</SUP>) each with two orbits divided among four filters (F105W, F125W, F140W, and F160W) and ACS imaging as needed to achieve single-orbit depth in each of three filters (F435W, F606W, and F814W). As previously reported by Salmon et al., we discovered over 300 <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a06\u201310 candidates, including the brightest <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a06 candidates known, and the most distant spatially resolved lensed arc known at <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a010. <I>Spitzer</I> IRAC imaging (945 hr awarded, plus 100 archival, spanning 3.0\u20135.0 <I>\u03bc</I>m) has crucially enabled us to distinguish <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidates from <I>z</I>\u00a0~\u00a02 interlopers. For each cluster, two <I>HST</I> observing epochs were staggered by about a month, enabling us to discover 11 supernovae, including 3 lensed supernovae, which we followed up with 20 orbits from our program. Reduced <I>HST</I> images, catalogs, and lens models are available on MAST, and reduced <I>Spitzer</I> images are available on IRSA.</P> </div>\n    <!-- End abstract -->\n<!-- Start Export citation and abstract tools -->\n\t<p>\n\t\t<small>Export citation and abstract</small>\n\t\t<span class=\"btn-multi-block\">\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/884/1/85&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b&exportFormat=iopexport_bib&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-bib\" title=\"Export BibTex\">BibTeX</a>\n\t\t\t<a href=\"/export?articleId=0004-637X/884/1/85&doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b&exportFormat=iopexport_ris&exportType=abs&navsubmit=Export+abstract\" class=\"btn btn-primary wd-btn-cit-abs-ris\" title=\"Export RIS\">RIS</a>\n\t\t</span>\n\t</p>\n<!-- End Export citation and abstract tools -->\n<!-- Start AAS Related Links -->\n<div class=\"reveal-container reveal-closed reveal-plus-icon bdt-1 mt-2 mb-2 wd-jnl-art-article-aas-related-links\">\n  <div class=\"replica-h3 mt-0\">\n    <a href=\"#\" class=\"reveal-trigger\" data-reveal-label-alt=\"Hide related links\">Related links</a>\n  </div>\n  <div class=\"reveal-content\">\n    <div class=\"article-meta\"> \n      <ul>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019ApJ...884...85C\" target=\"_blank\">NASA ADS Record <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://nedwww.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?refcode=2019ApJ...884...85C&search_type=Search \" target=\"_blank\">NED Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"http://simbad.u-strasbg.fr/simbad/sim-ref?querymethod=bib&simbo=on&bibcode=2019ApJ...884...85C\" target=\"_blank\">Simbad Objects <span class=\"icon-newtab\"></span></a></li>\n      \t<li><a href=\"/journal/0004-637X/page/About%20Related%20Links\" target=\"_blank\">About Related Links</a></li>\n      \t</ul>\n    </div>\n  </div>\n</div>\n<!-- Start info bottom -->\n    <!-- End info bottom -->\n<!-- Start article full text -->\n\t<div xmlns:book=\"http://api.iop.org/Book/1.0/\" itemprop=\"articleBody\" class=\"wd-jnl-art-full-text article-text\">\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs1\" name=\"apjab412bs1\">1.\u00a0Introduction</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>Gravitational lensing magnification by massive galaxy clusters has a long history of helping astronomers discover the most distant galaxies known with the <em>Hubble</em> <em>Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) and <em>Spitzer</em> (see Kneib &amp; Natarajan <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib98\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib98\">2011</a> Section 5.8 for a review). Twenty years ago, a <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a04.92 galaxy lensed by the cluster MS 1358+62 was the most distant known (Franx et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib61\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib61\">1997</a>). Ten years ago, that record belonged to A1689-zD1 at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a07.5 (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib22\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib22\">2008</a>; Watson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib209\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib209\">2015</a>). More recently, the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble (CLASH; Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>) yielded the triply imaged <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010.8 candidate MACS0647-JD (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>; Pirzkal et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib142\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib142\">2015</a>; Chan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib35\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib35\">2017</a>). This redshift has been surpassed only by the grism measurement of <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a011.1 (Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib132\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib132\">2016</a>) for GN-z11 discovered by Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib130\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib130\">2014</a> in blank-field imaging by the CANDELS program (Grogin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib67\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib67\">2011</a>; Koekemoer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib100\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib100\">2011</a>). Both <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a011 galaxies are similarly bright at 1.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m (F160W AB mag 25.9), making them excellent targets for follow-up study with the <em>James Webb Space Telescope</em> (<em>JWST</em>).</p><p>For a given observing strategy, lensed fields generally yield significantly more high-redshift galaxies than blank fields, especially at the highest redshifts and in relatively shallow imaging (e.g., Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>). Lensing does sacrifice high-redshift search volume owing to the magnification and the foreground cluster light. But lensing more than compensates for the lost volume by magnifying many more faint galaxies into view whenever luminosity function number counts are steeper than <em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>L</em><sup>\u22122</sup> (Broadhurst et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib28\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib28\">1995</a>). This is especially true brightward of <em>L</em>*, for example, AB mag ~28 at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a08 (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib23\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib23\">2012</a>; Finkelstein <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib58\">2016</a>).</p><p>CLASH demonstrated this lensing advantage, yielding significantly more galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20138 than blank-field surveys (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib24\">2014</a>). CLASH obtained 20-orbit <em>HST</em> imaging for each of 25 clusters in 16 filters, including F160W observed to AB mag 27.5 (5<em>\u03c3</em> depth; Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>; Molino et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib125\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib125\">2017</a>). The first 18 clusters yielded 262 candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20138 (Bradley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib24\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib24\">2014</a>), plus a few at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a09\u201311 (Zheng et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib216\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib216\">2012</a>; Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>; Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib15\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib15\">2014</a>).</p><p>The Frontier Fields (Lotz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib107\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib107\">2017</a>) obtained deeper 140-orbit <em>HST</em> imaging for each of six clusters and six blank parallel fields in seven filters, including F160W observed to AB mag 28.7. At these depths, <em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0<em>L</em><sup>\u22122</sup> for high-redshift galaxies (the luminosity function faint-end slope <em>\u03b1</em> ~ \u22122 roughly at <em>z</em> ~ 6 \u2212 8), so the lensed and blank-field high-<em>z</em> counts were predicted to be similar (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>). Indeed, the Frontier Fields yielded similar total numbers of lensed and blank-field high-redshift galaxies, altogether 453 at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20139 from one analysis (Kawamata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib93\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib93\">2018</a>), plus a few <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidates (Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib221\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib221\">2014</a>; Infante et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib81\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib81\">2015</a>; McLeod et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib120\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib120\">2016</a>; Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib131\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib131\">2018</a>). Due to their magnifications, the lensed galaxies are intrinsically fainter than the blank-field galaxies. By combining deep <em>HST</em> imaging with the power of gravitational lensing, the Frontier Fields revealed the faintest galaxies yet known, including some of those likely responsible for reionization at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06 (Livermore et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib106\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib106\">2017</a>; Atek et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib8\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib8\">2018</a>).</p><p>While CLASH and the Frontier Fields yielded many high-redshift candidates, neither survey was optimized to deliver high-redshift candidates observed brightly enough for detailed follow-up study with current and future observatories. Detailed studies are required to determine galaxies' ages, stellar masses, compositions, and ionizing strengths (see Stark <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib188\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib188\">2016</a> for a review). This knowledge can further inform how early galaxies enriched and reionized the universe (see Dayal &amp; Ferrara <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib47\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib47\">2018</a> for a review). It is imperative to use existing facilities to discover the best targets for study, ideally before <em>JWST</em> Cycle 1. Gravitational lensing offers the most efficient route to do this. The <em>Planck</em> all-sky survey delivered the PSZ2 catalog of &gt;1000 massive galaxy clusters (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib145\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib145\">2016a</a>) detected via their Sunyaev\u2013Zel'dovich (SZ) effect (Sunyaev &amp; Zeldovich <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib194\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib194\">1970</a>) on the cosmic microwave background (CMB). By searching the PSZ2 catalog, we found that many massive clusters (including presumably excellent lenses) lacked the combination of <em>HST</em> Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) and Wide Field Camera 3 infrared (WFC3/IR) imaging required to discover high-redshift candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06.</p><p>RELICS embarked on an efficient survey with <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> to discover the best and brightest high-redshift galaxies (Coe <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib40\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib40\">2018</a>). RELICS obtained five-orbit <em>HST</em> imaging of 41 clusters in seven filters (the same filters used by the Frontier Fields), including F160W to AB mag 26.5. Our relatively shallow imaging covered more area than CLASH or the Frontier Fields, yielding high-redshift candidates that are brighter, either intrinsically and/or due to lensing magnification. See Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt1\">1</a> for a summary comparison of CLASH, the Frontier Fields, and RELICS. More recently, a new <em>HST</em> program, BUFFALO (PIs Steinhardt &amp; Jauzac; GO 15117), has begun, extending the Frontier Fields to the wider area covered by deep <em>Spitzer</em> imaging.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt1\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 1.</b>\u00a0\nRecent Large <em>HST</em> Cluster Lensing Surveys\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt1\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt1_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 1\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">CLASH</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Frontier Fields</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">RELICS</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Clusters</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">25</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">6</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">41</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>HST</em> orbits per cluster</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">20<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt1fna\">a</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">140</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt1fna\">a</a></sup>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Total <em>HST</em> orbits</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">524</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">840</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">188</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Supernova orbits<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt1fnb\">b</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">50</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">20</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>HST</em> filters</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">16</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">7</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">7</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Depth in F160W<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt1fnc\">c</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">27.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">28.7</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">26.5</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>HST</em> Cycle numbers</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">18\u201320</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">21\u201323</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">23</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>HST</em> begin</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Nov 10</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Oct 13</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Oct 15</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>HST</em> end</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Jul 13</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Sept 16</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Apr 17</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt1fna\" id=\"apjab412bt1fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Depth including archival <em>HST</em> imaging.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt1fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt1fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup><em>HST</em> orbits allocated specifically for supernova follow-up.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt1fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt1fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>AB mag 5<em>\u03c3</em> depth for point sources.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt1_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt1_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Also notable and inspiring for this project are the <em>HST</em> Snapshot programs observing galaxy clusters discovered by the MAssive Cluster Survey (MACS; Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib54\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib54\">2001</a>). Shallower <em>HST</em> imaging (~1 orbit per cluster) has been obtained for 86 clusters to date (Repp &amp; Ebeling <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib158\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib158\">2018</a>). For 29 of these clusters, four-band imaging, including F140W to AB mag 26.6, was completed, yielding 20 candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a07\u20139 (Repp et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib159\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib159\">2016</a>). Nine MACS clusters are included in RELICS. Prior to RELICS, they had archival <em>HST</em> ACS and/or WFPC2 imaging, but not WFC3/IR or NICMOS.</p><p>Meanwhile, large <em>Spitzer</em> programs such as SURFS UP (Brada\u010d et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib20\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib20\">2014</a>; Ryan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib172\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib172\">2014</a>; Huang et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib80\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib80\">2016</a>) and the Frontier Fields have also surveyed many galaxy clusters, helping to identify high-redshift galaxies and study their properties (e.g., Hoag et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib76\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib76\">2019</a>). The Grism Lens-Amplified Survey from Space (Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib199\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib199\">2015</a>) delivered spectroscopic properties and high-redshift confirmations (e.g., Schmidt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib179\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib179\">2016</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib178\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib178\">2017</a>). The high-redshift searches in lensing programs complement searches in blank-field surveys such as the UDF, CANDELS, and BoRG, constraining luminosity functions from <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a04 to 10 (Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib17\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib17\">2015</a>; Finkelstein <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib58\">2016</a>; Morishita et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib126\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib126\">2018</a>; Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib131\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib131\">2018</a>).</p><p>Below we discuss the RELICS science drivers (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2\">2</a>); galaxy cluster targets (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs3\">3</a>); observations with <em>HST</em>, <em>Spitzer</em>, and other observatories (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs4\">4</a>); the image reductions and catalogs (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs5\">5</a>); results to date (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs6\">6</a>); and a summary (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs7\">7</a>).</p><p>We use the AB magnitude system, <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn1.gif\" alt=\"${m}_{\\mathrm{AB}}=31.4-2.5\\mathrm{log}({f}_{\\nu }/\\mathrm{nJy})$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{m}_{\\mathrm{AB}}=31.4-2.5\\mathrm{log}({f}_{\\nu }/\\mathrm{nJy})</script></span></span> (Oke <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib135\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib135\">1974</a>; Oke &amp; Gunn <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib136\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib136\">1983</a>). Where needed, we assume a flat concordance \u039bCDM cosmology with <em>h</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.7, \u03a9<sub><em>m</em></sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, and <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn2.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{{\\rm{\\Lambda }}}=0.7</script></span></span>, where <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0100  <em>h</em> km s<sup>\u22121</sup> Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>. Galaxy cluster masses are given as <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>, the mass enclosed within <em>r</em><sub>500</sub>, within which the average density is 500 times the critical density of the universe at that redshift (e.g., Coe <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib39\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib39\">2010</a>). These masses <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> are less than the total virial cluster masses measured at larger radii.</p></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs2\" name=\"apjab412bs2\">2.\u00a0Science</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>RELICS was primarily designed and optimized to search for brightly lensed high-redshift galaxies in the epoch of reionization. Ancillary science enabled by RELICS includes supernova (SN) searches, cluster mass measurements, and limits on the dark matter particle cross section. We discuss each of these science goals in turn.</p><h3 id=\"apjab412bs2-1\" name=\"apjab412bs2-1\">2.1.\u00a0High-redshift Galaxies</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p><em>HST</em>'s WFC3 has revealed ~2000 <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u201311 candidates from the universe's first billion years, but only a small fraction have been bright enough (<em>H</em> &lt; 25.5) for detailed follow-up study and spectroscopic confirmation (e.g., Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib17\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib17\">2015</a>; Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>). RELICS was designed primarily to deliver (1) brightly observed high-redshift candidates, amenable to more detailed studies; and (2) a large sample of high-redshift candidates to improve luminosity function constraints. This combination is required to improve our understanding of galaxies and reionization in the first billion years.</p><h4 id=\"apjab412bs2-1-1\" name=\"apjab412bs2-1-1\">2.1.1.\u00a0Spectroscopic Studies of Brightly Observed High-redshift Candidates</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Spectroscopic redshift confirmations based on Ly<em>\u03b1</em> detections have proven increasingly difficult beyond <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06 (Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib190\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib190\">2010</a>; Brada\u010d et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib21\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib21\">2012</a>; Schenker et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib175\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib175\">2014</a>; Schmidt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib179\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib179\">2016</a>; Hoag et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib76\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib76\">2019</a>; Mason et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib118\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib118\">2019</a>), likely due primarily to absorption by patchy neutral hydrogen before reionization was complete (Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib200\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib200\">2013</a>; Tilvi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib196\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib196\">2014</a>; Mason et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib119\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib119\">2018</a>). A higher success rate was achieved with four luminous <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a07\u20139 galaxies inferred to have significant [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]+H<em>\u03b2</em> equivalent width (EW) based on <em>Spitzer</em> photometry (Roberts-Borsani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib162\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib162\">2016</a>). All four yielded Ly<em>\u03b1</em> detections as distant as <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a08.68 (Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib133\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib133\">2015</a>; Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib219\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib219\">2015b</a>; Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib189\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib189\">2017</a>). This suggests that luminous galaxies with high ionization parameters carve out ionized gas bubbles allowing Ly<em>\u03b1</em> to stream free (Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib189\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib189\">2017</a>).</p><p>Alternatives to Ly<em>\u03b1</em> redshift confirmations include fainter, slightly redder UV metal lines such as N <span class=\"small-caps\">v</span><em>\u03bb</em>1243, C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span><em>\u03bb</em>1549, He <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span><em>\u03bb</em>1640, O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]<em>\u03bb</em>1663, and C <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]<em>\u03bb</em>1908 (Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib192\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib192\">2014</a>) and submillimeter lines such as [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m and [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 88 <em>\u03bc</em>m\u00a0(Inoue et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib82\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib82\">2014</a>). Studying these lines also yields more information about the physical properties of the galaxies, including their ionizing strength.</p><p>The UV metal line C <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] has been detected in several <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06 galaxies as distant as <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07.73 (Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib191\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib191\">2015</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib189\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib189\">2017</a>; Laporte et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib102\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib102\">2017a</a>; Mainali et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib111\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib111\">2018</a>). At <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02, Rigby et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib160\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib160\">2015</a>) found that lower-metallicity galaxies exhibit stronger C <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], likely explaining why C <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] appears far more often at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06 than at lower redshifts (see also Senchyna et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib180\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib180\">2017</a>; Du et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib49\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib49\">2017</a>; Le F\u00e8vre et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib104\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib104\">2019</a>). C <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] detections may be powered by low-metallicity massive stars (Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib191\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib191\">2015</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib189\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib189\">2017</a>) or may require active galactic nuclei (AGNs; Nakajima et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib128\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib128\">2018</a>). Still lower-metallicity stars (&lt;0.05<em>Z</em><sub>\u2299</sub>) produce higher ionization potentials yielding C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>. All three known <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06 C <span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> detections are lensed (Stark et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib191\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib191\">2015</a>; Hoag et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib77\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib77\">2017</a>; Mainali et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib110\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib110\">2017</a>) and thus less massive and presumably lower metallicity than average <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06 galaxies from current surveys.</p><p>Larger samples of UV metal line observations including RELICS galaxies will enable us to quantify the prevalence of these intense ionizing sources in the reionization epoch, both directly and by extrapolating to larger samples with similar observed properties (luminosity, rest-frame UV slope <em>\u03b2</em>, and Ly<em>\u03b1</em>). The observed EWs will also be very informative to future <em>JWST</em> surveys planning to observe these spectral features.</p><p>A new window for studying high-redshift galaxies has been opened by the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in the south and the Plateau de Bure interferometer (PdBI) in the north, later upgraded and renamed the Northern Extended Millimeter Array (NOEMA). These telescopes (primarily ALMA) have detected high-redshift galaxies by their infrared continuum dust emission (Capak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib30\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib30\">2015</a>), as well as spectral lines [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m and [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 88 <em>\u03bc</em>m, which trace star formation (De Looze et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib48\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib48\">2014</a>). Continuum observations show that <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a05\u20136 galaxies have at least an order of magnitude less dust than local starbursts with similar rest-frame UV colors (Capak et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib30\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib30\">2015</a>). Dust is often not detected at these redshifts, but at least a few galaxies have been found to be dusty and thus evolved as early as <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07.15 (Hashimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib72\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib72\">2019</a>), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07.5 (Watson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib209\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib209\">2015</a>), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a08.312 (Tamura et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib195\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib195\">2019</a>), and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a08.38 (Laporte et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib102\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib102\">2017a</a>).</p><p>[C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] 158 <em>\u03bc</em>m is one of the brightest lines in local galaxies (Malhotra et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib113\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib113\">1997</a>; Brauher et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib27\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib27\">2008</a>) and the strongest observed interstellar medium cooling line in <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01\u20132 galaxies (Stacey et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib187\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib187\">2010</a>). To date, [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] has been detected in 22 galaxies between 5.1533\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a07.1453 (Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib31\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib31\">2018</a> and references therein; Hashimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib72\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib72\">2019</a>), including two spatially resolved galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06.81 and 6.85 displaying disk-like rotation (Smit et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib185\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib185\">2018</a>).</p><p>At higher redshifts, Inoue et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib82\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib82\">2014</a>) predicted that [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 88 <em>\u03bc</em>m would yield more detections. While [C <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] is associated with neutral H <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span> gas in photodissociation regions (PDRs), [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] is associated with ionized H <span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> gas, more prevalent in higher-redshift, lower-metallicity galaxies with higher ionization states (Harikane et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib70\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib70\">2018</a>). As predicted, ALMA's highest-redshift spectroscopic confirmations have come from [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>], and the six <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a06 galaxies targeted to date have all yielded [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] detections at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a06.900 (Marrone et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib117\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib117\">2018</a>), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07.107 (Carniani et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib32\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib32\">2017</a>), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a07.212 (Inoue et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib83\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib83\">2016</a>), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a08.312 (Tamura et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib195\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib195\">2019</a>), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a08.382 (Laporte et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib103\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib103\">2017b</a>), and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a09.11 (Hashimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib73\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib73\">2018</a>). The two highest-redshift detections are lensed galaxies.</p><p>Based on this previous work, we expect RELICS to deliver ALMA confirmations and science at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u201310 (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs6-1\">6.1</a>).</p></div><h4 id=\"apjab412bs2-1-2\" name=\"apjab412bs2-1-2\">2.1.2.\u00a0Luminosity Functions of Galaxies at the Epoch of Reionization</h4><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Improving constraints on the <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a09 luminosity function (and the evolution from <em>z</em> ~ 10 to 6) is another primary science goal of RELICS. This is required to determine the numbers of faint galaxies available to reionize the universe.</p><p><em>Planck</em> constrained the reionization history by measuring the column density of free electrons to the CMB, or the Thomson scattering optical depth <em>\u03c4</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.058\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.012 (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib149\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib149\">2018a</a>). This value, lower than previous estimates, implies a later reionization halfway complete by <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a08, before fully completing by <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06. It also means that reionization can be achieved by galaxies producing less Lyman continuum (LyC) flux and with lower escape fractions <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub>. Direct measurements of these <em>f</em><sub>esc</sub> values have been obtained recently for ~40 galaxies with detected LyC leakage, including half extending from the local universe (e.g., Leitherer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib105\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib105\">2016</a>; Puschnig et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib153\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib153\">2017</a>) to <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a00.3 (e.g., Izotov et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib85\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib85\">2018</a>), with the other half at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02\u20134 (e.g., Shapley et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib183\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib183\">2016</a>; Rivera-Thorsen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib161\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib161\">2017</a>; Vanzella et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib205\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib205\">2018</a>). Assuming that these measurements hold at higher redshifts, and given high-redshift luminosity functions, low-mass galaxies could have produced most of the flux required to reionize the universe (e.g., Robertson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib164\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib164\">2015</a>; Madau <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib108\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib108\">2017</a>; Ishigaki et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib84\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib84\">2018</a>; Mason et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib119\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib119\">2018</a>; Finkelstein et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib59\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib59\">2019</a>). There may also have been significant contributions from low-luminosity AGN jets at <em>z</em>\u00a0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/gsim.gif\" alt=\"gsim\" align=\"baseline\" />\u00a06 (Bosch-Ramon <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib14\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib14\">2018</a>).</p><p>At the highest redshifts (<em>z</em> ~ 9\u201312), <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> imaging programs have yielded fewer candidates than expected. This has left luminosity functions highly uncertain at these redshifts, while also hinting at accelerated evolution in the first 600 Myr (Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib16\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib16\">2012</a>; Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib131\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib131\">2018</a>). Luminosity functions are fairly well constrained at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a04\u20138 (Bouwens et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib17\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib17\">2015</a>; Finkelstein <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib58\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib58\">2016</a>; Kawamata et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib93\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib93\">2018</a>). Only recently were constraints placed on all three parameters (<em><img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/phgr.gif\" alt=\"phgr\" align=\"absmiddle\" /></em>*, <em>M</em>*, <em>\u03b1</em>) of the <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a09 luminosity function (Morishita et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib126\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib126\">2018</a>); these results are consistent with either accelerated or smoother (nonaccelerated) evolution at <em>z</em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a08. Higher-precision measurements, especially with greater leverage at higher redshifts, are required to better constrain this early evolution rate.</p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs2-2\" name=\"apjab412bs2-2\">2.2.\u00a0Strong-lens Modeling</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Robust strong-lens modeling is required to estimate magnifications of our lensed galaxies and the survey volume. The mass in galaxy cluster cores responsible for the lensing is predominantly dark matter. We must infer the distribution of this dark matter based on observed strong lensing that produces multiple images of more distant galaxies. We often add the assumption that luminous galaxy cluster members are good tracers of their dark matter halos.</p><p>High-quality lens modeling generally requires multiband high-resolution <em>HST</em> imaging to reliably identify multiple images of strongly lensed galaxies based on their colors and morphologies. Spectroscopic redshifts are also crucial. Magnification accuracies improve with greater numbers of strongly lensed images with spectroscopic redshifts (Johnson &amp; Sharon <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib88\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib88\">2016</a>). Recent tests with simulated cluster lensing find that the best lens models accurately yield magnification estimates of 3 (10) with precisions of 15% (30%), with uncertainty increasing with magnification (Meneghetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib123\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib123\">2017</a>; see also Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib218\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib218\">2015a</a>). Such precision is encouraging, as the vast majority (over 80%) of lensed high-redshift galaxies observed are magnified by factors of 10 or less (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>).</p><p>Magnification uncertainties directly impact measurements of some physical properties such as luminosity, star formation rate, stellar mass, and size. However, since lensing is achromatic, other properties derived from galaxy colors are not affected by magnification; these include redshift, age, metallicity, extinction, and rest-frame UV slope. Magnifications do affect luminosity functions, but the uncertainties are mitigated by averaging over many galaxies. The resulting uncertainties on the total survey volume are subdominant compared to the current small number statistics at high redshifts (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>).</p><p>In the case of a multiply imaged high-redshift candidate, lens modeling can yield geometric support, distinguishing between low- and high-redshift solutions based on the separation between the observed images (e.g., Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>; Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib221\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib221\">2014</a>; Chan et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib35\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib35\">2017</a>). Lens modeling is required to study delensed (source plane) properties, including ~100 pc structures resolved in highly elongated arcs (e.g., Sharon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib184\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib184\">2012</a>; Johnson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib87\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib87\">2017</a>). Lens modeling is also required to constrain luminosity functions in lensed fields (e.g., Livermore et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib106\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib106\">2017</a>).</p><p>RELICS lens modeling is yielding the overall lensing strength for each cluster. While we expect all RELICS clusters to be excellent lenses, our analyses will reveal which are truly among the strongest and best to use for efficient discoveries of the most distant galaxies known in future surveys. For RELICS results to date, see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs6-2\">6.2</a>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs2-3\" name=\"apjab412bs2-3\">2.3.\u00a0Galaxy Cluster Masses</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Scaling relations linking mass estimates from lensing, X-ray, and SZ studies require understanding of observational systematics and scale-dependent cluster astrophysics. Improving the accuracy of these mass scaling relations will be key to realizing the full potential of future missions such as eROSITA, which anticipates detecting 100,000 clusters/groups out to <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01.3 (Pillepich et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib141\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib141\">2018</a>).</p><p>Constraints on cosmological parameters (primarily <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn3.gif\" alt=\"${{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{{\\rm{\\Omega }}}_{m}</script></span></span> and <em>\u03c3</em><sub>8</sub>) derived from the <em>Planck</em> CMB (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib146\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib146\">2016b</a>) are at odds with those derived from <em>Planck</em> SZ galaxy cluster counts (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib147\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib147\">2016c</a>). The latter paper calibrated the scaling relation between <em>Planck</em> SZ signal strength and cluster masses based on analyses of <em>XMM-Newton</em> X-ray observations assuming hydrostatic equilibrium (HSE). One may expect cluster masses to be ~20% greater owing to deviations from HSE, including nonthermal pressure support (e.g., Nagai et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib127\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib127\">2007</a>; Rasia et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib156\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib156\">2012</a>). But Planck Collaboration et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib147\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib147\">2016c</a>) found that the cosmology results can be reconciled only if one assumes that SZ-derived cluster masses underestimate the true <em>M</em><sub>500</sub> masses by <em>b</em>\u00a0\u2248\u00a042% (where they reported the mass bias as 1 \u2212 <em>b</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.58 \u00b1 0.04). That is about 2<em>\u03c3</em> greater than the ~20% initially adopted in the PSZ1 analysis (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib144\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib144\">2014</a>).</p><p>Weak-lensing analysis of clusters included in both the <em>Planck</em> analysis and the Weighing the Giants survey (WtG; von der Linden et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib208\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib208\">2014b</a>) shows that <em>Planck</em>\u00a0cluster masses may indeed be underestimated by ~42% for the most massive clusters (&gt;10<sup>15</sup><em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>), while <em>Planck</em> masses appear to be more accurate for less massive clusters (~5\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>14</sup><em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>). Subsequent weak-lensing analyses from various surveys (WtG, CCCP, LoCUSS, CLASH, CFHTLenS, RCSLenS, HSC-SSP) found a range of results, some consistent with WtG including bias increasing with mass (Sereno &amp; Ettori <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib182\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib182\">2017</a>), and others more consistent with the original <em>Planck</em> estimate of ~20% bias (Hoekstra et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib78\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib78\">2015</a>; Battaglia et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib9\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib9\">2016</a>; Smith et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib186\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib186\">2016</a>; Penna-Lima et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib139\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib139\">2017</a>; Medezinski et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib121\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib121\">2018</a>). Overall, the tension appears to be somewhat relieved, although not conclusively (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib151\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib151\">2018b</a>), especially after accounting for new <em>Planck</em> measurements of the reionization optical depth (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib150\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib150\">2016e</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib149\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib149\">2018a</a>).</p><p>SZ mass estimates are calibrated in part based on X-ray temperatures measured with spectroscopy out to <em>r</em><sub>500</sub>, which can be difficult, especially for higher-redshift clusters. X-ray mass calibration at the smaller <em>r</em><sub>2500</sub> radii probed by <em>HST</em> strong lensing may be key to improving mass scaling relations. These smaller radii are also important for ground-based SZ telescopes offering significantly higher resolution than <em>Planck</em>. Czakon et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib45\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib45\">2015</a>) analyzed arcsecond-resolution Bolocam SZ imaging of 45 clusters and found that the <em>Y</em><sub>SZ</sub> signal does not scale self-similarly with <em>M</em><sub>2500</sub> derived from X-ray observations. The cause of this mismatch may be due to AGN feedback regulating star formation and altering the gas properties in cluster cores. Through accurate lensing mass profiles measuring total mass, free from the assumption of gas HSE, and accurate gas mass profiles from <em>Chandra</em>, we will determine the radial dependence of <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>tot</sub> and characterize the efficiency with which AGNs input energy into the intracluster medium.</p><p>Long-term efforts to improve mass scaling relations focus on weak-lensing analyses, for example, from Euclid and LSST (Grandis et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib64\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib64\">2019</a>). However, strong-lensing analyses will also contribute. Simulations have shown that joint strong-lensing + weak-lensing analyses yield significantly smaller biases (~2%) and uncertainties (~20%) in virial mass estimates than either weak or strong lensing alone (Meneghetti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib122\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib122\">2010</a>). A joint strong-lensing plus weak-lensing analysis of 20 CLASH clusters based on <em>HST</em> and Subaru observations (Umetsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib203\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib203\">2016</a>) shows that the <em>M</em><sub>2500</sub> masses can be determined with a fractional total uncertainty of 25% per cluster at <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn4.gif\" alt=\"$\\langle {M}_{2500}\\rangle =3.6\\times {10}^{14}{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\langle {M}_{2500}\\rangle =3.6\\times {10}^{14}{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span> (or <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn5.gif\" alt=\"$\\langle {M}_{500}\\rangle ={10}^{15}{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">\\langle {M}_{500}\\rangle ={10}^{15}{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>), accounting for the dominant contributions from intrinsic profile variations (Gruen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib68\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib68\">2015</a>). Thus, a similar analysis of all 41 RELICS clusters would yield an overall mass calibration accuracy of about 4% from <em>r</em><sub>2500</sub> out to the virial radii, providing a legacy mass profile database for critical tests for models of background cosmology and structure formation.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs2-4\" name=\"apjab412bs2-4\">2.4.\u00a0Dark Matter Constraints</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Self-interacting dark matter (SIDM) particles with cross sections of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn6.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\sim 0.1\\mbox{--}0.6\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\sim 0.1\\mbox{--}0.6\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> have been invoked to explain several observational inconsistencies with collisionless cold dark matter (CDM) theory, including galaxy cluster density profiles, \"missing\" Milky Way satellites, and the \"cusp\u2013core\" problem (see Robertson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib163\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib163\">2019</a> and references therein). Baryonic processes can explain these \"problems\" with varying degrees of success. Merging galaxy clusters yield the most robust constraints on SIDM. As two clusters collide, galaxies pass straight through the collision, leaving the stripped cluster gas lagging behind. We expect dark matter to also pass straight through unless the particles have a significant self-interacting cross section. Joint <em>HST</em> lensing plus <em>Chandra</em> X-ray analysis of the Bullet Cluster (Clowe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib38\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib38\">2006</a>; Brada\u010d et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib19\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib19\">2006</a>) constrained <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn7.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\lt 1.25\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\lt 1.25\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> (68% confidence; Randall et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib155\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib155\">2008</a>). More recently, Harvey et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib71\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib71\">2015</a>) improved this constraint to <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn8.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\lt 0.47\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\lt 0.47\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}</script></span></span> (95% confidence) by jointly analyzing <em>HST</em> + <em>Chandra</em> imaging of 30 cluster mergers (Brada\u010d et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib18\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib18\">2008</a>; Dawson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib46\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib46\">2012</a>). However, Wittman et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib212\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib212\">2018</a>) subsequently analyzed more data (including more <em>HST</em> filters) on these same 30 clusters and claimed that the constraint should be more relaxed: <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn9.gif\" alt=\"${\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\lesssim 2\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{\\sigma }_{\\mathrm{DM}}/m\\lesssim 2\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>.</p><p>RELICS includes seven cluster mergers analyzed by these papers plus another 17 confirmed plus nine possible mergers not in their sample. Of the confirmed mergers, all but one have existing <em>Chandra</em> imaging. Joint analyses of the lens models plus X-ray data of these massive cluster mergers (specifically, those observed post-merger) will help constrain the SIDM parameter space toward the astrophysically and theoretically interesting limit of <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn10.gif\" alt=\"$0.1\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">0.1\\,{\\mathrm{cm}}^{2}\\,{{\\rm{g}}}^{-1}</script></span></span>.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs2-5\" name=\"apjab412bs2-5\">2.5.\u00a0Supernovae</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Large <em>HST</em> programs have yielded many distant SNe. CLASH and CANDELS discovered both Type Ia SNe (SNe Ia) and core-collapse SNe (CCSNe) out to <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.5. The observed SN Ia rates suggest that Type Ia progenitors are primarily double white dwarf systems (Graur et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib65\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib65\">2014</a>) that do not explode quickly after formation (Rodney et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib169\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib169\">2014</a>). High-<em>z</em> CCSN rates from these programs reinforced measurements of the cosmic star formation rate history and put constraints on the initial mass function for CCSN progenitors (Strolger et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib193\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib193\">2015</a>).</p><p>Lensed SNe Ia from CLASH and the Frontier Fields provided the first empirical tests verifying the accuracy of lens model magnification estimates (Nordin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib129\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib129\">2014</a>; Patel et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib137\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib137\">2014</a>; Rodney et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib168\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib168\">2015b</a>). The appearance of \"SN Refsdal\" (Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib95\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib95\">2015</a>) was the first strongly lensed SN observed as multiple images with measurable time delays (Rodney et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib170\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib170\">2016b</a>). These time delays can be used to test lens models (Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib96\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib96\">2016</a>; Treu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib198\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib198\">2016</a>) or as a cosmological distance measurement (Grillo et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib66\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib66\">2018</a>; Vega-Ferrero et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib206\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib206\">2018</a>). Strong-lensing clusters have also revealed other faint transient phenomena, including extreme magnifications of individual stars or stellar eruptions in galaxies at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.49 (Kelly et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib94\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib94\">2018</a>), <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.01 (Rodney et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib167\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib167\">2018</a>), and <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.94 (Chen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib36\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib36\">2019</a>; Kaurov et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib91\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib91\">2019</a>).</p><p>RELICS observed each cluster in two epochs separated by ~40 days to identify SNe and other transient phenomena. This cadence was designed to catch <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a01\u20132 SNe near peak brightness in epoch 2. Our primary goal was to significantly contribute to the numbers of known distant and lensed SNe discovered in previous surveys. Ultimately, RELICS discovered 11 SNe (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs6-3\">6.3</a>). The RELICS proposal included 20 orbits for follow-up imaging to confirm and obtain light curves for the more interesting candidates. RELICS observations will also provide a baseline for the longer-term (decade) monitoring required to detect higher-redshift SNe and other lensed transients, perhaps including individual Population III stars (Windhorst et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib211\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib211\">2018</a>).</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs3\" name=\"apjab412bs3\">3.\u00a0Galaxy Clusters</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>RELICS observed the 41 massive galaxy clusters at 0.182\u00a0\u2264\u00a0<em>z</em>\u00a0\u2264\u00a00.972 listed in Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt2\">2</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt3\">3</a>. None had existing <em>HST</em> infrared imaging (WFC3/IR or NICMOS) prior to RELICS. As shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab412bf1\">1</a>, we selected 21 of the clusters based on exceptionally high mass estimates from <em>Planck</em> and the other 20 based on other factors revealing or suggesting exceptional lensing strength, including details noted in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt3\">3</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab412bf1\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bf1\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf1_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 1.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 1.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf1_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 1.</strong>\u00a0RELICS clusters marked as red squares on a plot of mass vs.\u00a0redshift for the 1094 clusters in the Planck PSZ2 catalog. Each cluster is plotted as a circle color-coded according to existing <em>HST</em> imaging prior to RELICS, prioritizing WFC3/IR (red) followed by NICMOS (salmon), ACS and/or UVIS (aqua), and finally WFPC2 (green). Clusters without <em>HST</em> imaging prior to RELICS are colored white. Frontier Fields and CLASH clusters are plotted as filled yellow diamonds and blue squares, respectively. A dashed line at 8.7\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>14</sup><em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> separates the 21 clusters selected solely by mass from the other 20 selected based on various criteria, including existing imaging revealing lensing strength. Note that two RELICS clusters are not plotted here, as they were not included in the Planck PSZ2 catalog.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf1\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf1\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf1\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt2\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 2.</b>\u00a0\nRELICS Clusters\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt2\"
