colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">MACS J0025.4-1222</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\"Baby Bullet\"</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">macs0025-12</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">41</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">CL J0152.7\u20131357</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">\u00a0</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">cl0152-13</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fna\" id=\"apjab412bt3fna\"></a><sup> a</sup><em>JWST</em> GTO target (CANUCS; PI Willott).\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt3fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup><em>JWST</em> GTO target (PI Windhorst).\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt3fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>Optical counterpart is 4<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcm.gif\" alt=\"farcm\" align=\"baseline\" />5 from PSZ1 coordinates (2:27:06, +49:05:10) from Planck Collaboration et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib148\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib148\">2016d</a>).\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fnd\" id=\"apjab412bt3fnd\"></a><sup> d</sup>Discovered by Wen et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib210\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib210\">2012</a>) based on photometric redshifts in SDSS-III. Renamed in the PSZ2 catalog with coordinates given in decimal degrees (Alternate Name above).\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fne\" id=\"apjab412bt3fne\"></a><sup> e</sup>Wong et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib213\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib213\">2013</a>) #7: seventh most powerful lensing line of sight expected based on LRGs identified in SDSS.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fnf\" id=\"apjab412bt3fnf\"></a><sup> f</sup><em>HST</em> observations centered on MACS0358 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.428); includes some contribution from A3192 (<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.168). See Hamilton-Morris et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib69\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib69\">2012</a>) and Hsu et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib79\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib79\">2013</a>).\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fng\" id=\"apjab412bt3fng\"></a><sup> g</sup>Wong et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib213\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib213\">2013</a>) #59.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt3fnh\" id=\"apjab412bt3fnh\"></a><sup> h</sup>Frontier Fields contender (ultimately not selected).\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt3_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt3_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Planck Collaboration et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib145\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib145\">2016a</a>) identified 1653 SZ (Sunyaev &amp; Zeldovich <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib194\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib194\">1970</a>) sources in their PSZ2 all-sky (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn51.gif\" alt=\"$| b| \\gt 15^\\circ $\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">| b| \\gt 15^\\circ</script></span></span>) catalog,<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn1\">36</a></sup>\n including 1203 confirmed clusters, 1094 of which had measured redshifts and SZ mass estimates. A few hundred of these were newly discovered clusters, including some of the most massive known.</p><p>We queried the <em>HST</em> observations of all the <em>Planck</em> clusters using the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST).<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn2\">37</a></sup>\n Many had existing <em>HST</em> imaging prior to RELICS, but many more did not.</p><p>The 34 most massive clusters (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn52.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{500}\\gt 8.8\\times {10}^{14}{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{500}\\gt 8.8\\times {10}^{14}{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>) include some already well studied by <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em>, including 4/6 Frontier Fields clusters<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn3\">38</a></sup>\n and 5/25 from CLASH (with three common to both surveys). But others were less well studied. Nine of the top 34 had yet to be observed by <em>HST</em> or <em>Spitzer</em> at all, and 12 more had yet to be observed by <em>HST</em> in the near-infrared with NICMOS or WFC3. These 21 clusters compose half of the RELICS sample; RELICS obtained the first <em>HST</em> infrared imaging of these clusters, and <em>Spitzer</em> imaging as needed.</p><p>The remaining 20 RELICS clusters are primarily known strong lenses based on existing <em>HST</em> optical imaging (or ground-based imaging in the case of RXC 0232-44; Kausch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib92\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib92\">2010</a>). Existing <em>HST</em> ACS imaging, where available, reduced our total orbit request. We also considered other factors in this selection, including X-ray mass estimates (Mantz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib115\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib115\">2010</a>; MCXC Piffaretti et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib140\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib140\">2011</a>), weak-lensing mass estimates (Sereno <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib181\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib181\">2015</a> compilation including Weighing the Giants; Applegate et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib7\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib7\">2014</a>; von der Linden et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib207\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib207\">2014a</a>; Umetsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib202\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib202\">2014</a>; Hoekstra et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib78\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib78\">2015</a>), SDSS clusters (Wen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib210\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib210\">2012</a>; Wong et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib213\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib213\">2013</a>), and other SZ mass estimates from SPT (Bleem et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib13\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib13\">2015</a>) and ACT (Hasselfield et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib74\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib74\">2013</a>), as well as clusters nearly selected for the Frontier Fields.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn4\">39</a></sup>\n\n</p><p>The 41 RELICS clusters generally bear the names of the surveys that discovered them: Abell (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib1\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib1\">1958</a>); Abell et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib2\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib2\">1989</a>); the Einstein Observatory Extended Medium-Sensitivity Survey (MS; Gioia et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib62\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib62\">1990</a>); the <em>ROSAT</em> X-ray All-Sky Galaxy Cluster Survey (RXC; Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib52\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib52\">1998</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib51\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib51\">2000a</a>); the <em>ROSAT</em> MAssive Cluster Survey (MACS and SMACS; Ebeling et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib54\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib54\">2001</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib50\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib50\">2007</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib55\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib55\">2010</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib53\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib53\">2013</a>; Mann &amp; Ebeling <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib114\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib114\">2012</a>; Repp et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib159\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib159\">2016</a>; Repp &amp; Ebeling <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib158\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib158\">2018</a>); an extended radio source discovered in <em>ROSAT</em> (RXS; van Weeren et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib204\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib204\">2012</a>); the Wen, Han, &amp; Liu SDSS-III cluster catalog (WHL; Wen et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib210\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib210\">2012</a>); the South Pole Telescope SZ survey (SPT; Bleem et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib13\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib13\">2015</a>); the Atacama Cosmology Telescope SZ survey (ACT; Hasselfield et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib74\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib74\">2013</a>); and the <em>Planck</em> all-sky SZ survey (Planck Collaboration et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib143\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib143\">2011</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib145\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib145\">2016a</a>). CL J0152.7\u20131357 at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.833 was discovered by Ebeling et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib56\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib56\">2000b</a>) in the Wide Angle <em>ROSAT</em> Pointed Survey (WARPS). Alternate cluster names include one also identified in the Rosat Bright Survey (RBS; Kausch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib92\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib92\">2010</a>) and another in Clusters in the Zone of Avoidance (CIZA; Kocevski et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib99\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib99\">2007</a>).</p><p>The Abell clusters are numbered sequentially based on the original catalog. Numbers in other cluster names codify coordinates, often in J2000 R.A. HH:MM and decl. DD:MM. <em>Planck</em> cluster names, instead, give Galactic coordinates in longitude and latitude. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt3\">3</a> lists names and any alternate names for each RELICS target. Their positions on the sky are shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab412bf2\">2</a>.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab412bf2\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bf2\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf2_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 2.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 2.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf2_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 2.</strong>\u00a0Distribution on the sky of the 41 RELICS clusters relative to the Galactic and ecliptic planes. The background is color-coded to show the Galactic extinction map from Schlegel et al. (<a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib177\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib177\">1998</a>). Numbers correspond to ordered Planck mass as given in Table <a class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt2\">2</a>.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf2\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf2\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf2\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs4\" name=\"apjab412bs4\">4.\u00a0Observations</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>All data from our large <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> observing programs had no proprietary period. We describe each of these programs in turn, followed by other subsequent large observing programs of RELICS clusters.</p><h3 id=\"apjab412bs4-1\" name=\"apjab412bs4-1\">4.1.\u00a0<em>HST</em> Imaging</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Of the 41 RELICS clusters, 28 had been observed previously by <em>HST</em> with ACS and/or WFC3/UVIS (Tables <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt4\">4</a> and <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt5\">5</a>). Our 188-orbit <em>HST</em> Treasury Program (Cycle 23; GO 14096; PI Coe; Deputy PI Bradley) obtained additional observations with ACS and WFC3/IR (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt6\">6</a>). Five clusters required two WFC3/IR pointings for a total of 46 new WFC3/IR images of strongly lensed fields. For each field, we observed two orbits of WFC3/IR split among four filters: F105W, F125W, F140W, and F160W (Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab412bf3\">3</a>). And for each cluster, we observed three orbits of ACS split among F435W, F606W, and F814W, minus any archival imaging. For the 18 RELICS clusters without any existing ACS imaging, we observed the full three orbits of ACS and, in parallel, three orbits of WFC3 on a blank field: one orbit of WFC3/UVIS F350LP and two orbits of WFC3/IR F105W, F125W, F140W, and F160W. The parallels use the same filters as in BoRG[z9\u201310] (Calvi et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib29\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib29\">2016</a>; Morishita et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib126\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib126\">2018</a>), adding area to our high-<em>z</em> search.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab412bf3\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bf3\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf3_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 3.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 3.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf3_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 3.</strong>\u00a0RELICS clusters were observed with the seven <em>HST</em> ACS and WFC3/IR filters shown here. RELICS parallels were observed with the one WFC3/UVIS and four WFC3/IR filters shown. Response curves are plotted vs. wavelength (<em>\u03bb</em>), with the corresponding Ly<em>\u03b1</em> redshift (<em>z</em>) given along the top axis (<em>\u03bb</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.1216<em>\u03bc</em>m (1+<em>z</em>)). F350LP, F105W, and F140W are offset vertically for clarity. Black dots mark the effective \"pivot\" wavelengths (Tokunaga &amp; Vacca <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib197\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib197\">2005</a>) of the filters.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf3\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf3\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf3\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt4\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 4.</b>\u00a0\nArchival <em>HST</em> ACS and WFC3/UVIS Imaging of RELICS Clusters\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt4\" id=\"apjab412bt4fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Multiple pointings with minimal or no overlap are given in superscript brackets. Total exposure times listed should be divided by the numbers [2] or [4] to give the depth at each position.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt4fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt4fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>WFC3/UVIS observations. (All other archival observations listed are ACS.)\n<a name=\"apjab412bt4fnd\" id=\"apjab412bt4fnd\"></a><sup> d</sup>2\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a02 mosaic plus one extra central pointing; dividing that exposure time by 2.5 yields 5088 s within the central pointing.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt6fnc\">c</a></sup>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt6fna\" id=\"apjab412bt6fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Observations were split between two pointings.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt6fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt6fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>PLCK G287+32 was also awarded Cycle 23 observations under GO 14165 (PI Seitz). In addition to the four ACS orbits in F475W, F606W, and F814W listed in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt4\">4</a>, that program also obtained four orbits (10,447 s) of WFC3/IR F110W imaging. RELICS observed this cluster in ACS F435W and WFC3/IR F105W, F125W, F140W, and F160W, relinquishing the two awarded orbits of F606W and F814W imaging that would have been duplicated.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt6fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt6fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>Indicates WFC3 orbits added for SN follow-up observations (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt7\">7</a>). For those clusters, \"Time between WFC3 Epochs\" refers to the first two epochs.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt6_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt6_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>For each cluster, we split the observations into two epochs separated by 25\u201363 days (typically ~40; see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt6\">6</a>). This enabled searches for SNe and other transients. Twenty orbits of RELICS were allocated to follow up such Targets of Opportunity (ToO). We executed these orbits on three of the nine SNe discovered by RELICS (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt7\">7</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" time available between Earth occultations and the time to acquire or reacquire guide stars. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt8\">8</a> gives the total integration times in each filter for A1763, as a representative example. For most other clusters, the integration times were slightly longer (by up to 15%). Each integration was split into four exposures at different dither positions (pointings). We dithered across the ACS chip gap and WFC3/IR \"death star\" to fill these gaps in the data.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt8\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">108</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt8fna\" id=\"apjab412bt8fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Effective \"pivot\" wavelength (Tokunaga &amp; Vacca <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib197\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib197\">2005</a>).\n<a name=\"apjab412bt8fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt8fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Total integration times for A1763; slightly longer integrations were obtained for most other clusters. Much deeper <em>SST</em> integrations (30 hr) were obtained for 10 RELICS clusters.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt8fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt8fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>5<em>\u03c3</em> point-source AB magnitude limit. <em>HST</em>: within a 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4 diameter aperture assuming exposure time is split into four integrations. <em>SST</em>: assuming medium background with 180 integrations of 100 s each.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt8fnd\" id=\"apjab412bt8fnd\"></a><sup> d</sup>1<em>\u03c3</em> point-source sensitivity (nJy) within the same apertures.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt8_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt8_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt9\">9</a> gives the detailed breakdown of epochs, orbits, and exposure times at each of the four dither positions in each filter for a nominal target with no archival imaging. In the parallel fields, note that the WFC3/UVIS F350LP imaging consists of four exposures at four dither positions, but the parallel WFC3/IR imaging consists of only two exposures in each filter (one per epoch).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt9\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 9.</b>\u00a0\nNominal <em>HST</em> Exposures for a Cluster and Parallel Field valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">2/5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Y</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">F160W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">453</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">2/5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Y</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">F125W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">230</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong> Each epoch begins with ACS on the prime cluster field and WFC3 in parallel and ends with WFC3/IR in prime. Epochs 1 and 2 are separated by about a month, or longer when possible.</p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt9fna\" id=\"apjab412bt9fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Each ACS dither position (ABCD) takes another step across the chip gap. The WFC3/IR dither positions consist of two close (~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8) pairs (WX and YZ) separated by a larger distance (~6<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5) to cover the \"death star.\"\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt9_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt9_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs4-2\" name=\"apjab412bs4-2\">4.2.\u00a0<em>Spitzer</em> Imaging</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Altogether, RELICS has been awarded 945 hr of <em>Spitzer</em> observing time (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt10\">10</a>). For each cluster, we obtained IRAC imaging as needed in the two warm mission filters, ch1 (3.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m) and ch2 (4.5 <em>\u03bc</em>m). Combined, these filters span approximately 3\u20135 <em>\u03bc</em>m. About 100 hr of archival IRAC imaging were also available for 18 of the clusters in these two filters, most notably from GO 60034 (PI Egami). Below we summarize the complete <em>Spitzer</em> RELICS data sets, which will be detailed further by V. Strait et al.\u00a0(2019, in preparation).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt10\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 10.</b>\u00a0\n<em>Spitzer</em> IRAC Imaging Programs\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt10\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt10_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 10\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Program</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">PI</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">TAC</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Hours<sup>a</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Depth<sup>b</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Clusters<sup>c</sup>\n</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">12005</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">GO</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">99.9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">26</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">12123</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Soifer</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">DDT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">290</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">34</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">13165</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">DDT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">167</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">13210</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">DDT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">55.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">14017</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">GO</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">333.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">6</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt10fna\" id=\"apjab412bt10fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Total hours awarded, including overheads.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt10fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt10fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Resulting total hours observed in each IRAC filter (ch1, ch2) for each cluster, including previous observations.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt10fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt10fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>Number of RELICS clusters observed. The first two programs observed all clusters as required to reach target depths. The final three programs observed 10 clusters to achieve 30 hr depth for each.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt10_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt10_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Our initial 100 hr SRELICS (<em>Spitzer</em> RELICS) program (Cycle 12; GO 12005; PI Brada\u010d) was supplemented by a 290 hr Director's Discretionary Time program (DDT 12123; PI Soifer). Combined, these programs observed all RELICS clusters (as needed) to achieve a total of 5 hr of integration time (combining new and archival imaging) in each of the two IRAC filters. The five clusters requiring two WFC3/IR pointings also required two IRAC pointings.</p><p>Subsequently, based on our analyses of the <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> images, we were awarded three more proposals (PI Brada\u010d) to obtain deeper IRAC imaging (30 hr/band), requiring an additional 556 hr on the 10 clusters yielding the most high-<em>z</em> candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u201310 (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>). DDT 13165 observed PLCK G287.0+32.9, PLCK G004.5\u201319.5, and A1763. DDT 13210 observed SPT-CL J0615\u20135746 and the <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 arc discovered by Salmon et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>). And GO 14017 observed CL J0152.7\u20131357, ACT-CL J0102\u201349151, PLCK G308.3\u201320.2, RXS J060313.4+421, MS 1008.1\u20131124, and SMACS J0723.3\u20137327.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs4-3\" name=\"apjab412bs4-3\">4.3.\u00a0Other Large Surveys of RELICS Clusters</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In addition to the large <em>HST</em> and <em>SST</em> observing programs, RELICS has also motivated large surveys with other telescopes, including VST, VISTA, <em>XMM-Newton</em>, ALMA, and VLA (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11\">11</a>). The VLA survey exclusively observes RELICS clusters, while the other listed programs have most or just some clusters in common with RELICS. We have also carried out smaller follow-up programs with many other observatories, including Keck MOSFIRE and DEIMOS, VLT MUSE and X-SHOOTER, Gemini GMOS, Subaru SuprimeCam and HSC, Magellan MegaCam and LDSS3, MMT Hectospec, and GMRT. Spectra from Magellan LDSS3 have already been used in several papers (Cerny et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib34\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib34\">2018</a>; Paterno-Mahler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib138\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib138\">2018</a>; Mainali et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib222\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib222\">2019</a>). Also note that while we are advertising these newer surveys here, we also emphasize that many RELICS clusters have been observed previously by large programs carried out with <em>HST</em>, <em>Spitzer</em>, <em>Chandra</em>, <em>XMM-Newton</em>, and ground-based observatories.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt11\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 11.</b>\u00a0\nLarge Surveys Including RELICS Clusters Motivated in Part by RELICS\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt11\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt11_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 11\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Name</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">PI</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Observatory</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Instrument</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Time</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Wavelength</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">RELICS/Total Clusters</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">RELICS<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11fna\">a</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Coe</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>HST</em></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS, WFC3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">115 hr</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.4\u20131.7 <em>\u03bc</em>m</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">41</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">S-RELICS<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11fnb\">b</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Brada\u010d; Soifer</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>Spitzer</em></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">IRAC</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">945 hr</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3\u20135 <em>\u03bc</em>m</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">34<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11fnc\">c</a></sup>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">GAME</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Mercurio</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">VST</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">OmegaCAM</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">300 hr</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">ugri</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">9/12</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">GCAV<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11fnd\">d</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Nonino</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">VISTA</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">VIRCAM</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">540 hr</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">YJKs</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">13/20</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Witnessing<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11fne\">e</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Arnaud &amp; Ettori</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><em>XMM-Newton</em></td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">EPIC</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">833 hr</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.15\u201315 keV</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">18/118</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ALCS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" hr</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.1 mm</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">16/33</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Probing<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11fnf\">f</a></sup>\n</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">van Weeren</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">VLA</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">25 m array</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">85 hr</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">2\u20134 GHz</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">34<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11fng\">g</a></sup>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong> The RELICS clusters were observed by many previous programs, including MACS <em>HST</em> snapshot programs and large <em>Spitzer</em> programs (see Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs1\">1</a>). This table does not include those, instead summarizing the more recent programs inspired in part by the RELICS program.</p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fna\" id=\"apjab412bt11fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://relics.stsci.edu\">https://relics.stsci.edu</a>\n\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt11fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/SRELICS/overview.html\">https://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/SPITZER/SRELICS/overview.html</a>\n\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt11fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>The remaining seven RELICS clusters already had archival 5 hr depth, and none of them were targeted for 30 hr depth.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fnd\" id=\"apjab412bt11fnd\"></a><sup> d</sup>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://archive.eso.org/cms/eso-archive-news/first-data-release-from-the-galaxy-clusters-at-vircam-gcav-eso-vista-public-survey.html\">http://archive.eso.org/cms/eso-archive-news/first-data-release-from-the-galaxy-clusters-at-vircam-gcav-eso-vista-public-survey.html</a>\n\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fne\" id=\"apjab412bt11fne\"></a><sup> e</sup>Witnessing the culmination of structure formation in the universe.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fnf\" id=\"apjab412bt11fnf\"></a><sup> f</sup>Probing cosmic star formation with the JVLA Lensing Cluster Survey.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fng\" id=\"apjab412bt11fng\"></a><sup> g</sup>All RELICS clusters accessible to VLA.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt11_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt11_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs5\" name=\"apjab412bs5\">5.\u00a0Image Reductions and Catalogs</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have made our <em>HST</em> reduced images and catalogs publicly available via MAST<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn5\">40</a></sup>\n at doi:<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"dataset\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\" data-art-data-content-type=\"External repository\" data-toolbar-link=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\" data-toolbar-title=\"MAST dataset\" data-art-data-type=\"ext-rep-mast\" id=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\">10.17909/T9SP45</a> and our <em>Spitzer</em> reduced images available via IRSA.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn6\">41</a></sup>\n Below we describe the procedures used to generate these data products.</p><h3 id=\"apjab412bs5-1\" name=\"apjab412bs5-1\">5.1.\u00a0<em>HST</em> Image Reductions</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We reduced all <em>HST</em> images obtained by RELICS and all archival <em>HST</em> ACS and WFC3/IR images that overlap with the RELICS WFC3/IR images. Our <em>HST</em> image reduction procedure is similar to that performed on the Frontier Fields <em>HST</em> images (Lotz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib107\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib107\">2017</a>). Key differences are that we do not produce \"self-calibrated\" ACS images (due to insufficient numbers of exposures), nor do we correct for time-variable sky emission due to helium line emission at 1.083 <em>\u03bc</em>m, which occasionally affects WFC3/IR F105W images (Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib25\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib25\">2014</a>).</p><p>We correct all <em>HST</em> images for bias, dark current, and flat fields with up-to-date reference files (as noted in the FITS headers of our final reduced images). We manually identified and masked any satellite trails. ACS images were corrected for charge transfer efficiency (CTE) and bias striping. The multiple ACS exposures were used to automatically identify and reject cosmic rays. Each WFC3/IR MULTIACCUM exposure consists of multiple samples, enabling \"up-the-ramp\" cosmic-ray rejection. We also masked bad pixels using updated identifications in WFC3/IR images from GO 14114 (G. Brammer 2019, private communication).</p><p>We produced inverse variance maps (IVMs) quantifying the uncertainty in each pixel before accounting for correlated pixel noise (an additional 10%\u201315%) and Poisson source noise. These IVMs were used as weights to drizzle-combine the images obtained in each filter.</p><p>For each cluster or parallel field, we aligned all processed <em>HST</em> images to two common grids with 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />06 and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />03 resolution. These are meant to adequately sample the point-spread functions (PSFs) in the WFC3/IR images (FWHM\u00a0~\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />18) and ACS images (FWHM\u00a0~\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />09), respectively. We used procedures from DrizzlePac, specifically AstroDrizzle (Gonzaga et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib63\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib63\">2012</a>), and as outlined in Koekemoer et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib101\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib101\">2002</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib100\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib100\">2011</a>) and Lotz et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib107\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib107\">2017</a>). We set the drizzle parameter <tt>p</tt>ixfrac\u00a0=\u00a00.8, as used in programs such as CANDELS (see discussion in Section 5.8.2 of Koekemoer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib100\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib100\">2011</a>).</p><p>We corrected the absolute astrometry of our images using the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>) point-source catalog (Wright et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib214\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib214\">2010</a>).</p><p>Finally, we produced automatically scaled color images using Trilogy (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib43\">2012</a>). Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab412bf4\">4</a> show <em>HST</em> ACS + WFC3 color images of all 46 WFC3/IR cluster fields observed by RELICS. The ACS color images extend to wider areas, which are not shown here but are available on MAST. Also on MAST are color images of the 18 RELICS parallel fields observed with WFC3 UVIS and IR.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab412bf4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bf4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf4a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf4f_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0<em>HST</em> ACS + WFC3/IR observations of RELICS clusters within the WFC3/IR footprints. ACS imaging extends to wider areas not shown. All images are shown to the same scale. North is up; east is left. Color images produced using Trilogy (Coe et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib43\">2012</a>): blue\u00a0=\u00a0F435W; green\u00a0=\u00a0F606W + F814W; red\u00a0=\u00a0F105W + F125W + F140W + F160W.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf4f\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf4f\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf4f\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf4f\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs5-2\" name=\"apjab412bs5-2\">5.2.\u00a0<em>HST</em> Detection and Photometry Catalogs</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Based on the 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />06 resolution <em>HST</em> images, we produced source catalogs using techniques similar to those employed for the public CLASH catalogs (Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>; Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>) and the Frontier Fields analysis presented in Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>.</p><p>We ran SExtractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib12\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib12\">1996</a>) version 2.8.6 in dual-image mode to detect objects in each field and define their isophotal apertures for photometry to be measured in each filter image. For each field, we produce two source catalogs:</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>acs-wfc3</tt> (or <tt>acs-wfc3ir</tt>): based on detections in a weighted stack of all <em>HST</em> images (ACS, WFC3/UVIS, and WFC3/IR), optimized to detect most objects.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>wfc3ir</tt>: based on detections in a weighted stack of WFC3/IR images only using a finer background grid and more aggressive deblending, optimized to detect smaller high-redshift galaxies.</div></li></ul><p>\n</p><p>The stacked images are weighted sums; the weights are the IVMs produced by the drizzling software (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs5-1\">5.1</a>). For SExtractor input, we also produce rms maps equal to 1/sqrt(weight).</p><p>Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt12\">12</a> lists the SExtractor parameters used for the <tt>acs-wfc3</tt> and <tt>wfc3ir</tt> catalogs. The latter is geared toward detections of small high-redshift galaxies, so we use a smaller background grid and more aggressive deblending to detect small objects near brighter ones. The <tt>acs-wfc3</tt> catalogs cover the full (larger) ACS field of view and aim to detect whole objects, breaking them apart less often.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt12\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 12.</b>\u00a0\nSExtractor Parameters Used in the RELICS <em>HST</em> Source Catalogs\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt12\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt12_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 12\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SExtractor Parameter</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>acs-wfc3</tt></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>wfc3ir</tt></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Description</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>ETECT_MINAREA</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Contiguous pixels required above detection threshold</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>ETECT_THRESH</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Detection threshold (<em>\u03c3</em> above background rms)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACK_SIZE</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">128</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">64</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Background cell size</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACK_FILTERSIZE</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Background grid size</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>EBLEND_NTHRESH</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">32</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">64</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Number of threshold levels</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>EBLEND_MINCONT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.0015</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.0001</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Minimum contrast ratio</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACKPHOTO_TYPE</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>L</tt>OCAL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>L</tt>OCAL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Method for measuring background</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACKPHOTO_THICK</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>2</tt>4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>2</tt>4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Width of rectangular annulus around each object</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt12_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt12_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>For detections in either catalog, 9 contiguous pixels are required at the level of the observed background rms or higher. The <tt>acs-wfc3</tt> (<tt>wfc3ir</tt>) background is calculated in 5\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a05 (3\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a03) grids of cells with 128\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a0128 (64\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a064) pixels in each cell. We set the deblending of adjacent objects to 128 (64) levels of 0.0015 (0.0001) minimum contrast.</p><p>Each object's detection defines an isophotal aperture, which SExtractor uses in dual-image mode to measure isophotal photometry in every filter in the aligned images. Just outside this aperture, we have SExtractor use a 24-pixel-wide rectangular annulus around each object to estimate and subtract the local background in each filter. We do not perform aperture corrections, as the PSF FWHMs only vary between ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />07 and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />15 and we use relatively large isophotal apertures (see discussion in Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>, Section 5.1).</p><p>Finally, we correct all photometry for Galactic extinction using the IR dust emission maps of Schlafly &amp; Finkbeiner (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib176\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib176\">2011</a>).<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn7\">42</a></sup>\n Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt2\">2</a> gives the extinction <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>) for each cluster from those maps. These are multiplied by coefficients <em>A</em><sub><em>\u03bb</em></sub> (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt13\">13</a>) for each filter to determine the extinction in magnitudes.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt13\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 13.</b>\u00a0\nGalactic Reddening Extinction Correction Coefficients <em>A</em><sub><em>\u03bb</em></sub> for Each Filter\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt13\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt13_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt14\">14</a> summarizes the output in our <em>HST</em> catalogs available on MAST. Samples are provided from our A697 IR-detection catalog for object detection and shape measurement (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt15\">15</a>), photometry (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt16\">16</a>), and Bayesian photometric redshifts (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt17\">17</a>), which are discussed below.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt14\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 14.</b>\u00a0\n<em>HST</em> Source Catalog Content\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt14\" photometric redshift</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">65</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">zbmin</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\"
