align=\"center\">1</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong> The full list of RELICS SN discoveries is given in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt18\">18</a>.</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt7_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt7_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Total integration times for each <em>HST</em> orbit vary with the time available between Earth occultations and the time to acquire or reacquire guide stars. Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt8\">8</a> gives the total integration times in each filter for A1763, as a representative example. For most other clusters, the integration times were slightly longer (by up to 15%). Each integration was split into four exposures at different dither positions (pointings). We dithered across the ACS chip gap and WFC3/IR \"death star\" to fill these gaps in the data.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt8\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey Much deeper <em>SST</em> integrations (30 hr) were obtained for 10 RELICS clusters.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt8fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt8fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>5<em>\u03c3</em> point-source AB magnitude limit. <em>HST</em>: within a 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />4 diameter aperture assuming exposure time is split into four integrations. <em>SST</em>: assuming medium background with 180 integrations of 100 s each.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt8fnd\" id=\"apjab412bt8fnd\"></a><sup> d</sup>1<em>\u03c3</em> point-source sensitivity (nJy) within the same apertures.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt8_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt8_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt9\">9</a> gives the detailed breakdown of epochs, orbits, and exposure times at each of the four dither positions in each filter for a nominal target with no archival imaging. In the parallel fields, note that the WFC3/UVIS F350LP imaging consists of four exposures at four dither positions, but the parallel WFC3/IR imaging consists of only two exposures in each filter (one ACS on the prime cluster field and WFC3 in parallel and ends with WFC3/IR in prime. Epochs 1 and 2 are separated by about a month, or longer when possible.</p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt9fna\" id=\"apjab412bt9fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Each ACS dither position (ABCD) takes another step across the chip gap. The WFC3/IR dither positions consist of two close (~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />8) pairs (WX and YZ) separated by a larger distance (~6<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5) to cover the \"death star.\"\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt9_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt9_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs4-2\" name=\"apjab412bs4-2\">4.2.\u00a0<em>Spitzer</em> Imaging</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Altogether, RELICS has been awarded 945 hr of <em>Spitzer</em> observing time (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt10\">10</a>). For each cluster, we obtained IRAC imaging as needed in the two warm mission filters, ch1 (3.6 <em>\u03bc</em>m) and ch2 (4.5 <em>\u03bc</em>m). Combined, these filters span approximately 3\u20135 <em>\u03bc</em>m. About 100 hr of archival IRAC imaging were also available for 18 of the clusters in these two filters, most notably from GO 60034 (PI Egami). Below we summarize the complete <em>Spitzer</em> RELICS data sets, which will be detailed further by V. Strait et al.\u00a0(2019, in preparation).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt10\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 10.</b>\u00a0\n<em>Spitzer</em> IRAC Imaging Programs\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt10\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt10_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 10\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Program</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">PI</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">TAC</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Hours<sup>a</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Depth<sup>b</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Clusters<sup>c</sup>\n</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">12005</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">GO</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">99.9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">26</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">12123</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Soifer</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">DDT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">290</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">34</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">13165</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">DDT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">167</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">13210</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">DDT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">55.5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">14017</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Brada\u010d</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">GO</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">333.2</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">30</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">6</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt10fna\" id=\"apjab412bt10fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Total hours awarded, including overheads.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt10fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt10fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Resulting total hours observed in each IRAC filter (ch1, ch2) for each cluster, including previous observations.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt10fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt10fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>Number of RELICS clusters observed. The first two programs observed all clusters as required to reach target depths. The final three programs observed 10 clusters to achieve 30 hr depth for each.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt10_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt10_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>Our initial 100 hr SRELICS (<em>Spitzer</em> RELICS) program (Cycle 12; GO 12005; PI Brada\u010d) was supplemented by a 290 hr Director's Discretionary Time program (DDT 12123; PI Soifer). Combined, these programs observed all RELICS clusters (as needed) to achieve a total of 5 hr of integration time (combining new and archival imaging) in each of the two IRAC filters. The five clusters requiring two WFC3/IR pointings also required two IRAC pointings.</p><p>Subsequently, based on our analyses of the <em>HST</em> and <em>Spitzer</em> images, we were awarded three more proposals (PI Brada\u010d) to obtain deeper IRAC imaging (30 hr/band), requiring an additional 556 hr on the 10 clusters yielding the most high-<em>z</em> candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u201310 (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>). DDT 13165 observed PLCK G287.0+32.9, PLCK G004.5\u201319.5, and A1763. DDT 13210 observed SPT-CL J0615\u20135746 and the <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 arc discovered by Salmon et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>). And GO 14017 observed CL J0152.7\u20131357, ACT-CL J0102\u201349151, PLCK G308.3\u201320.2, RXS J060313.4+421, MS 1008.1\u20131124, and SMACS J0723.3\u20137327.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs4-3\" name=\"apjab412bs4-3\">4.3.\u00a0Other Large Surveys of RELICS Clusters</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>In addition to the large <em>HST</em> and <em>SST</em> observing programs, RELICS has also motivated large surveys with other telescopes, including VST, VISTA, <em>XMM-Newton</em>, ALMA, and VLA (see Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt11\">11</a>). The VLA survey exclusively observes RELICS clusters, while the other listed programs have most or just some clusters in common with RELICS. We have also carried out smaller follow-up programs with many other observatories, including Keck MOSFIRE and DEIMOS, VLT MUSE and X-SHOOTER, Gemini GMOS, Subaru SuprimeCam and HSC, Magellan MegaCam and LDSS3, MMT Hectospec, and GMRT. Spectra from Magellan LDSS3 have already been used in several papers (Cerny et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib34\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib34\">2018</a>; Paterno-Mahler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib138\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib138\">2018</a>; Mainali et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib222\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib222\">2019</a>). Also note that while we are advertising these newer surveys here, we also emphasize that many RELICS clusters have been observed previously by large programs carried out with <em>HST</em>, <em>Spitzer</em>, <em>Chandra</em>, <em>XMM-Newton</em>, and ground-based observatories.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt11\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 11.</b>\u00a0\nLarge Surveys Including RELICS Clusters Motivated in Part by RELICS\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt11\" name=\"apjab412bt11fne\" id=\"apjab412bt11fne\"></a><sup> e</sup>Witnessing the culmination of structure formation in the universe.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt11fnf\" id=\"apjab412bt11fnf\"></a><sup> class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt11_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt11_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs5\" name=\"apjab412bs5\">5.\u00a0Image Reductions and Catalogs</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We have made our <em>HST</em> reduced images and catalogs publicly available via MAST<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn5\">40</a></sup>\n at doi:<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"dataset\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\" data-art-data-content-type=\"External repository\" data-toolbar-link=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\" data-toolbar-title=\"MAST dataset\" data-art-data-type=\"ext-rep-mast\" id=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\">10.17909/T9SP45</a> and our <em>Spitzer</em> reduced images available via IRSA.<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn6\">41</a></sup>\n Below we describe the procedures used to generate these data products.</p><h3 id=\"apjab412bs5-1\" name=\"apjab412bs5-1\">5.1.\u00a0<em>HST</em> Image Reductions</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We reduced all <em>HST</em> images obtained by RELICS and all archival <em>HST</em> ACS and WFC3/IR images that overlap with the RELICS WFC3/IR images. Our <em>HST</em> image reduction procedure is similar to that performed on the Frontier Fields <em>HST</em> images (Lotz et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib107\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib107\">2017</a>). Key differences are that we do not produce \"self-calibrated\" ACS images (due to insufficient numbers of exposures), nor do we correct for time-variable sky emission due to helium line emission at 1.083 <em>\u03bc</em>m, which occasionally affects WFC3/IR F105W images (Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib25\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib25\">2014</a>).</p><p>We correct all <em>HST</em> images for bias, dark current, and flat fields with up-to-date reference files (as noted in the FITS headers of our final reduced images). We manually identified and masked any satellite trails. ACS images were corrected for charge transfer efficiency (CTE) and bias striping. The multiple ACS exposures were used to automatically identify and reject cosmic rays. Each WFC3/IR MULTIACCUM exposure consists of multiple samples, enabling \"up-the-ramp\" cosmic-ray rejection. We also masked bad pixels using updated identifications in WFC3/IR images from GO 14114 (G. Brammer 2019, private communication).</p><p>We produced inverse variance maps (IVMs) quantifying the uncertainty in each pixel before accounting for correlated pixel noise (an additional 10%\u201315%) and Poisson source noise. These IVMs were used as weights to drizzle-combine the images obtained in each filter.</p><p>For each cluster or parallel field, we aligned all processed <em>HST</em> images to two common grids with 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />06 and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />03 resolution. These are meant to adequately sample the point-spread functions (PSFs) in the WFC3/IR images (FWHM\u00a0~\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />18) and ACS images (FWHM\u00a0~\u00a00<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />09), respectively. We used procedures from DrizzlePac, specifically AstroDrizzle (Gonzaga et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib63\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib63\">2012</a>), and as outlined in Koekemoer et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib101\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib101\">2002</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib100\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib100\">2011</a>) and Lotz et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib107\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib107\">2017</a>). We set the drizzle parameter <tt>p</tt>ixfrac\u00a0=\u00a00.8, as used in programs such as CANDELS (see discussion in Section 5.8.2 of Koekemoer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib100\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib100\">2011</a>).</p><p>We corrected the absolute astrometry of our images using the <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>) point-source catalog (Wright et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib214\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib214\">2010</a>).</p><p>Finally, we produced automatically scaled color images using Trilogy (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib43\">2012</a>). Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab412bf4\">4</a> show <em>HST</em> ACS + WFC3 color images of all 46 WFC3/IR cluster fields observed by RELICS. The ACS color images extend to wider areas, which are not shown here but are available on MAST. Also on MAST are color images of the 18 RELICS parallel fields observed with WFC3 UVIS and IR.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab412bf4\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bf4\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf4a_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 4.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf4a_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf4a\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf4a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf4a\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf4a\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf4e_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf4e\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf4e\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf4e\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf4e\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 4.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf4f_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 4.</strong>\u00a0<em>HST</em> ACS + WFC3/IR observations of RELICS clusters within the WFC3/IR footprints. ACS imaging extends to wider areas not shown. All images are shown to the same scale. North is up; east is left. Color images produced using Trilogy (Coe et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib43\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib43\">2012</a>): blue\u00a0=\u00a0F435W; green\u00a0=\u00a0F606W + F814W; red\u00a0=\u00a0F105W + F125W + F140W + F160W.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf4f\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf4f\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf4f\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf4f\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs5-2\" name=\"apjab412bs5-2\">5.2.\u00a0<em>HST</em> Detection and Photometry Catalogs</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Based on the 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />06 resolution <em>HST</em> images, we produced source catalogs using techniques similar to those employed for the public CLASH catalogs (Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>; Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>) and the Frontier Fields analysis presented in Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>.</p><p>We ran SExtractor (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib12\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib12\">1996</a>) version 2.8.6 in dual-image mode to detect objects in each field and define their isophotal apertures for photometry to be measured in each filter image. For each field, we produce two source catalogs:</p><ul class=\"clear-list wd-inline-list\"><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">1.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>acs-wfc3</tt> (or <tt>acs-wfc3ir</tt>): based on detections in a weighted stack of all <em>HST</em> images (ACS, WFC3/UVIS, and WFC3/IR), optimized to detect most objects.</div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"\" id=\"\">2.\u00a0\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><tt>wfc3ir</tt>: based on detections in a weighted stack of WFC3/IR images only using a finer background grid and more aggressive deblending, optimized to detect smaller high-redshift galaxies.</div></li></ul><p>\n</p><p>The stacked images are weighted sums; the weights are the IVMs produced by the drizzling software (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs5-1\">5.1</a>). For SExtractor input, we also produce rms maps equal to 1/sqrt(weight).</p><p>Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt12\">12</a> lists the SExtractor parameters used for the <tt>acs-wfc3</tt> and <tt>wfc3ir</tt> catalogs. The latter is geared toward detections of small high-redshift galaxies, so we use a smaller background grid and more aggressive deblending to detect small objects near brighter ones. The <tt>acs-wfc3</tt> catalogs cover the full (larger) ACS field of view and aim to detect whole objects, breaking them apart less often.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt12\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 12.</b>\u00a0\nSExtractor Parameters Used in the RELICS <em>HST</em> Source Catalogs\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt12\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt12_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 12\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">SExtractor Parameter</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>acs-wfc3</tt></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>wfc3ir</tt></th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Description</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>ETECT_MINAREA</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">9</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Contiguous pixels required above detection threshold</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>ETECT_THRESH</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Detection threshold (<em>\u03c3</em> above background rms)</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACK_SIZE</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">128</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">64</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Background cell size</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACK_FILTERSIZE</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">5</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Background grid size</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>EBLEND_NTHRESH</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">32</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">64</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Number of threshold levels</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>D</tt>EBLEND_MINCONT</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.0015</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.0001</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Minimum contrast ratio</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACKPHOTO_TYPE</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>L</tt>OCAL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>L</tt>OCAL</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Method for measuring background</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\"><tt>B</tt>ACKPHOTO_THICK</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>2</tt>4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\"><tt>2</tt>4</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Width of rectangular annulus around each object</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt12_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt12_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>For detections in either catalog, 9 contiguous pixels are required at the level of the observed background rms or higher. The <tt>acs-wfc3</tt> (<tt>wfc3ir</tt>) background is calculated in 5\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a05 (3\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a03) grids of cells with 128\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a0128 (64\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a064) pixels in each cell. We set the deblending of adjacent objects to 128 (64) levels of 0.0015 (0.0001) minimum contrast.</p><p>Each object's detection defines an isophotal aperture, which SExtractor uses in dual-image mode to measure isophotal photometry in every filter in the aligned images. Just outside this aperture, we have SExtractor use a 24-pixel-wide rectangular annulus around each object to estimate and subtract the local background in each filter. We do not perform aperture corrections, as the PSF FWHMs only vary between ~0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />07 and 0<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />15 and we use relatively large isophotal apertures (see discussion in Postman et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib152\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib152\">2012</a>, Section 5.1).</p><p>Finally, we correct all photometry for Galactic extinction using the IR dust emission maps of Schlafly &amp; Finkbeiner (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib176\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib176\">2011</a>).<sup xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"fnref\"><a class=\"fnref\" href=\"#apjab412bfn7\">42</a></sup>\n Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt2\">2</a> gives the extinction <em>E</em>(<em>B</em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>V</em>) for each cluster from those maps. These are multiplied by coefficients <em>A</em><sub><em>\u03bb</em></sub> (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt13\">13</a>) for each filter to determine the extinction in magnitudes.</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt13\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 13.</b>\u00a0\nGalactic Reddening Extinction Correction Coefficients <em>A</em><sub><em>\u03bb</em></sub> for Each Filter\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt13\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt13_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 13\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col><col align=\"left\" char=\"\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Camera</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Filter</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">Coefficient</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">WFC3/UVIS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F390W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">4.514</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F475W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">3.747</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F555W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">3.242</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS, WFC3/UVIS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F606W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">2.929</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F625W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">2.671</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F775W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">2.018</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F814W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.847</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">ACS</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F850LP</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.473</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">WFC3/IR</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F105W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">1.015</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">WFC3/IR</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F110W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"char\" char=\".\">0.876</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">WFC3/IR</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">F125W</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" image</a></span></p></div><p>Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt14\">14</a> summarizes the output in our <em>HST</em> catalogs available on MAST. Samples are provided from our A697 IR-detection catalog for object detection and shape measurement (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt15\">15</a>), photometry (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt16\">16</a>), and Bayesian photometric redshifts (Table <a rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(<em>e</em><sup>\u2212</sup> s<sup>\u22121</sup>)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">(nJy)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">S/N</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">28.4629\u00b10.4579</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">0.0760\u00b10.0399</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">14.9573\u00b17.8473</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.9100</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">24.2190\u00b10.0567</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">3.7868\u00b10.2031</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">745.4248\u00b139.9764</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">18.6500</td>\n</tr>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u22120.1387\u00b10.0619</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">\u221227.3093\u00b112.1918</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">1.0059\u00b10.0765</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">198.0041\u00b115.0577</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"center\">13.1500</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Note.</strong> Continuation of sample provided in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt15\">15</a>. Parameters are described in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt14\">14</a>. The photometry given here is from the F435W filter. In the full catalog, all filters are provided, followed by the brightest magnitude in any filter for reference.</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt16_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt16_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt17\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 17.</b>\u00a0\n<em>HST</em> Source Catalog: Photometric Redshifts\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt17\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt17_lr.gif\" href=\"#apjab412bt15\">15</a>. Parameters are described in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt14\">14</a>.</p>\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt17_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt17_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div><p>As a caution to users, we note that the source catalogs include image artifacts such as diffraction spikes and objects poorly segmented by SExtractor. Additionally, photometry is complicated in crowded fields, especially as brighter cluster members contaminate the light from fainter, more distant objects.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs5-3\" name=\"apjab412bs5-3\">5.3.\u00a0Photometric Redshifts</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Based on the <em>HST</em> photometry, we measured photometric redshifts using Bayesian Photometric Redshifts (BPZ; Ben\u00edtez <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib10\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib10\">2000</a>; Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib41\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib41\">2006</a>) and Easy and Accurate <em>z</em><sub>phot</sub> from Yale (EAZY; Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib26\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib26\">2008</a>), which were two of the top performing methods in controlled tests (Hildebrandt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib75\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib75\">2010</a>).</p><p>For BPZ, we used 11 spectral models shown in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab412bf5\">5</a> and described in Coe et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a>), Ben\u00edtez et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib11\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib11\">2014</a>), and Rafelski et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib154\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib154\">2015</a>). Briefly, the model spectral energy distributions (SEDs) are originally from PEGASE (Fioc &amp; Rocca-Volmerange <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib60\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib60\">1997</a>) but recalibrated, based on observed photometry and spectroscopic redshifts from FIREWORKS (Wuyts et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib215\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib215\">2008</a>). The templates were selected to encompass ranges of metallicities, extinctions, and star formation histories observed for the vast majority of real galaxies. We allowed BPZ to interpolate nine templates between each pair of adjacent templates, yielding 101 templates altogether. BPZ fit the photometry to a grid of these 101 templates and 1300 redshifts linearly spaced from <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.001 to <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a013. BPZ tempers those <em>\u03c7</em><sup>2</sup> results with a Bayesian prior <span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn53.gif\" alt=\"$P(z,T| m)$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">P(z,T| m)</script></span></span>, which gives the likelihood of a redshift <em>z</em> and template type <em>T</em> given an observed magnitude <em>m</em> in F814W. We used the original BPZ prior derived from the HDFN (Ben\u00edtez <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib10\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib10\">2000</a>) and plotted in Figure <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" href=\"#apjab412bf6\">6</a> for <em>m</em>\u00a0=\u00a024, 26, and \u226532, the latter including F814W nondetections. We do not attempt to correct magnitudes for lensing magnifications in our initial catalogs because those estimates are not available from the start. We note that our prior's dependence on magnitude is often gradual, but magnification should be accounted for in a more accurate <em>P</em>(<em>z</em>) estimate.</p><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab412bf5\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bf5\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf5_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 5.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 5.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf5_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 5.</strong>\u00a0The 11 BPZ template SEDs used in this work, consisting of four elliptical galaxies (Ell), one lenticular (ES0), and four starbursts (SB). These templates are based on PEGASE (Fioc &amp; Rocca-Volmerange <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib60\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib60\">1997</a>) but recalibrated based on observed photometry and spectroscopic redshifts from FIREWORKS (Wuyts et al. <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib215\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib215\">2008</a>). The starbursts and Scd spiral contain emission lines, four of which are labeled in gray. All spectra are normalized to the same magnitude at 1 <em>\u03bc</em>m.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf5\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf5\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf5\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><figure xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" id=\"apjab412bf6\" tabindex=\"-1\" role=\"group\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\" data-toolbar-type=\"figure\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bf6\" data-toolbar-img=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf6_lr.jpg\" data-toolbar-title=\"Figure 6.\"><figure><div class=\"panzoom-container\"><div class=\"panzoom-parent\" style=\"overflow: hidden; position: relative;\"><img class=\"panzoom\" alt=\"Figure 6.\" src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bf6_lr.jpg\" style=\"transform: matrix(1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0); backface-visibility: hidden; transform-origin: 50% 50% 0px; cursor: move; transition: transform 200ms ease-in-out 0s;\"></img></div><div class=\"buttons zoom-tools\"><button class=\"zoom-in\"><span class=\"icon-zoomin\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom In\n\t\t\t\t</button><button class=\"zoom-out\"><span class=\"icon-zoomout\"></span>\n\t                 Zoom Out\n\t\t\t\t</button><span class=\"mobile-block\"><button class=\"reset\"><span class=\"icon-loop\"></span>\n\t                     Reset image size\n\t\t\t\t\t</button></span></div></div><figcaption><div class=\"article-text figure-caption\"><p><strong>Figure 6.</strong>\u00a0For BPZ, we use the Bayesian redshift prior derived from the HDFN (Ben\u00edtez <a class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib10\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib10\">2000</a>). Here we show priors for galaxies of different spectral types and with F814W AB magnitudes of 24, 26, and \u226532, including nondetections.</p></div><p class=\"mb-05 print-hide\">Download figure:</p><span class=\"btn-multi-block print-hide\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-std-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-std-img-apjab412bf6\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadFigure/figure/apjab412bf6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> Standard image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary fig-dwnld-hi-img\" id=\"wd-jnl-art-btn-hires-img-apjab412bf6\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/downloadHRFigure/figure/apjab412bf6\"><span class=\"icon-image\"></span> High-resolution image\n\t\t\t\t\t</a></span></figcaption></figure></figure><p>We used EAZY (Brammer et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib26\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib26\">2008</a>) to obtain a second independent set of photometric redshift estimates. EAZY uses a different template set and allows interpolation between any pair of templates. The nine templates used here include seven from PEGASE, one very dusty and quiescent galaxy from Maraston (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib116\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib116\">2005</a>), and one extreme emission line galaxy (EELG) from Erb et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib57\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib57\">2010</a>). We used a flat prior with EAZY, as we found that the default prior was systematically biased against high-redshift galaxies, strongly preferring lower-redshift EELGs with worse fits to the photometry (see discussion in Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>).</p><p>Salmon et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>) present a comparison of the templates and results from BPZ and EAZY for RELICS high-<em>z</em> candidates.</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs5-4\" name=\"apjab412bs5-4\">5.4.\u00a0<em>Spitzer</em> Image Reductions</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>We reduced the <em>Spitzer</em> images using MOPEX (Makovoz &amp; Khan <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib112\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib112\">2005</a>) and generated catalogs using T-PHOT (Merlin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib124\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib124\">2015</a>). The reduced images are available via IRSA. Currently these include data from programs 12005 and 12123 (totaling 5 hr of depth per filter). Deeper data from the additional three <em>Spitzer</em> programs (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt10\">10</a>) will be included in future releases of reduced images. More details will be presented by V. Strait et al.\u00a0(2019, in preparation). Due to the broader <em>Spitzer</em> PSF, extra care is required in obtaining aperture-matched <em>HST</em> + <em>Spitzer</em> photometry. Less careful <em>Spitzer</em> photometry can result in less accurate photometric redshifts (Hildebrandt et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib75\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib75\">2010</a>). We did not use the <em>Spitzer</em> photometry in our initial photometric redshift catalog release. We did use the <em>Spitzer</em> photometry to vet our <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidates, and we will use it to study the properties of all our high-redshift candidates.</p></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs6\" name=\"apjab412bs6\">6.\u00a0Results</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>To date, RELICS has delivered the following science results on high-redshift galaxies (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-1\">2.1</a>), strong-lens modeling (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-2\">2.2</a>), and SNe (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-5\">2.5</a>). Reduced images, catalogs, and lens models are available via MAST and IRSA. Constraints on cluster masses (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-3\">2.3</a>) and the dark matter particle cross section (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-4\">2.4</a>) require weak-lensing data and analyses on a longer timescale.</p><h3 id=\"apjab412bs6-1\" name=\"apjab412bs6-1\">6.1.\u00a0High-redshift Candidates</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>RELICS yielded over 300 high-redshift candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20138, including the brightest known at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06 (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>). These galaxies are lensed as brightly as F160W <em>H</em>\u00a0~\u00a023, enabling detailed studies of galaxy properties in the first billion years. Follow-up study is beginning to match some of these candidates as multiple images (Acebron et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib4\">2018</a>) and deliver spectroscopic confirmations (Cibirka et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib37\">2018</a>). We are following up RELICS high-redshift candidates with ground-based telescopes and instruments, including Keck/MOSFIRE, VLT/MUSE, Gemini/GMOS, Gemini-S/Flamingos-2, ALMA, and NOEMA/PdBI.</p><p>RELICS also delivered SPT0615-JD, the most distant lensed arc known (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>). At <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 and spanning a full 2<img src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/icons/Entities/farcs.gif\" alt=\"farcs\" align=\"bottom\" />5 on the sky, SPT0615-JD provides by far the most detailed view we have of any galaxy in the first 500 million years. (The two known <em>z</em> ~ 11 galaxies are not spatially resolved, despite lensing magnification in the case of MACS0647-JD from Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib44\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib44\">2013</a> and the relatively high intrinsic luminosity of GN-z11 from Oesch et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib132\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib132\">2016</a>.) ALMA observations have been awarded (PI Tamura) to search for the [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] 88 <em>\u03bc</em>m line in the <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 lensed arc, continuing the success of that research group at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a07\u20139 as noted in Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-1\">2.1</a> (Inoue et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib83\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib83\">2016</a>; Hashimoto et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib73\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib73\">2018</a>; Tamura et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib195\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib195\">2019</a>). An [O <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] detection would yield the highest spectroscopic redshift confirmation to date, along with the earliest detection of heavy elements (oxygen).</p><p>RELICS <em>Spitzer</em> (SRELICS) imaging was crucial in distinguishing between bonafide <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidates and <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 interlopers. Salmon et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>) actually identified three <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidates based on our <em>HST</em> imaging, but two turned out to be <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 interlopers based on the <em>Spitzer</em> photometry. Red <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 galaxies are significantly brighter at 3\u20135 <em>\u03bc</em>m than bluer <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 galaxies. RELICS <em>Spitzer</em> imaging will also enable us to measure stellar masses for our &gt;300 candidates at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20138.</p><p>Improved constraints on the <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a09 luminosity function from RELICS will require adding simulating lensed galaxies to our images to quantify our detection efficiency as a function of magnitude, position, and redshift (e.g., Livermore et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib106\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib106\">2017</a>; Carrasco et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib33\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib33\">2018</a>). But based on our current lack of any strong <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a09 candidates and a single <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidate (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>), our yields appear lower than expected at these redshifts, which may support the accelerated evolution scenario. Alternatively, more detailed study may shed light on why we have missed galaxies at these redshifts in our searches and photometric redshift analyses.</p><p>At lower redshifts, RELICS is studying compact, low-metallicity dwarf galaxies that are excellent analogs to high-redshift galaxies but can be studied in greater detail. Analysis of one RELICS <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a01.645 galaxy shows that low-metallicity stars are driving C <span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] emission with the strongest rest-frame EW (~20 \u00c5) yet observed at these redshifts, suggesting a more intense radiation field than assumed by most population synthesis models (Mainali et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib222\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib222\">2019</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs6-2\" name=\"apjab412bs6-2\">6.2.\u00a0Lens Modeling</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>Strong-lens models of RELICS clusters are primarily used to estimate magnifications of our lensed galaxies and to correct the surveyed volume for lensing magnification (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-2\">2.2</a>). We use three lens modeling methods, all of which assume that the observed cluster light traces some component of the cluster mass distribution: Lenstool (Kneib et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib97\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib97\">1996</a>; Jullo &amp; Kneib <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib90\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib90\">2009</a>; Johnson et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib89\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib89\">2014</a>); Zitrin LTM, or light-traces-mass (Zitrin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib217\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib217\">2009</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib219\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib219\">2015b</a>); and GLAFIC (Oguri <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib134\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib134\">2010</a>). The use of multiple methods on an individual cluster yields a more accurate estimate of systematic uncertainties than using one method alone, as shown in analyses of Frontier Fields clusters (Coe et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib42\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib42\">2015</a>; Acebron et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib5\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib5\">2017</a>; Livermore et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib106\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib106\">2017</a>; Remolina Gonz\u00e1lez et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib157\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib157\">2018</a>).</p><p>RELICS has published strong-lens modeling analyses of 14 clusters to date (Acebron et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib4\">2018</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib3\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib3\">2019</a>; Cerny et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib34\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib34\">2018</a>; Cibirka et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib37\">2018</a>; Paterno-Mahler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib138\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib138\">2018</a>; Mahler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib109\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib109\">2019</a>). These models are based on the multiband <em>HST</em> imaging and spectroscopic redshifts of strongly lensed galaxies obtained by our group and others. Most of these analyses have revealed lensing strengths on par with Frontier Fields clusters, quantified in terms of cumulative area with magnification greater than some threshold. Strong-lens models are currently available on MAST for 28/41 RELICS clusters, with the rest to be delivered in time for the <em>JWST</em> GO call for proposals. Our data products include maps of cluster mass, as well as lensing deflection, shear, and magnification.</p><p>Paterno-Mahler et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib138\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib138\">2018</a>) used all three methods (primarily Lenstool) to model SPT0615-57 and study the <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 candidate discovered by Salmon et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>). They delivered magnification estimates and explained the current lack of observed counterimages. Acebron et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib3\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib3\">2019</a>) compared magnification estimates from two methods (Zitrin LTM and Lenstool) for the many (24) <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20137 candidates lensed by CL0152-13. Acebron et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib4\">2018</a>) modeled two clusters with the Zitrin LTM method, including MACS0308+26, which lenses one of the brightest <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06 candidates known. This paper identified two multiple images of that galaxy lensed to <em>J</em>\u00a0~\u00a023.2 and 24.6 AB. Mahler et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib109\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib109\">2019</a>) used spectroscopic redshifts of many arcs from VLT/MUSE (Jauzac et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib86\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib86\">2019</a>) to produce a detailed Lenstool model of MACS0417-11, confirming that it is a strong lens, despite curiously yielding no <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u20138 candidates (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>). Cibirka et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib37\">2018</a>) modeled four clusters using the LTM method and presented one lensed galaxy showing strong Ly<em>\u03b1</em> emission with a spectroscopic redshift <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a05.800. Cerny et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib34\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib34\">2018</a>) modeled five clusters using Lenstool and presented detailed estimates of the statistical and systematic uncertainties. They present new spectroscopic redshifts and a new method to mitigate modeling uncertainties due to photometric redshifts.</p><p>Wide-field imaging for weak-lensing analyses from Subaru and Magellan is in hand for many RELICS clusters, as are X-ray data from <em>Chandra</em> and <em>XMM-Newton</em>, along with <em>Planck</em> SZ mass measurements. Combining these with strong-lensing mass measurements from <em>HST</em> will improve both precision and accuracy on the overall mass calibration of massive clusters (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-3\">2.3</a>) and contribute to constraints on the dark matter particle cross section (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-4\">2.4</a>).</p></div><h3 id=\"apjab412bs6-3\" name=\"apjab412bs6-3\">6.3.\u00a0Supernovae</h3><div class=\"article-text\"><p>The RELICS observing strategy (Section <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"secref\" href=\"#apjab412bs2-5\">2.5</a>) yielded 11 SNe, summarized here for the first time in Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt18\">18</a>. Most of these are cluster members, as expected. The first three SNe, all found in the RXC 0949+17 cluster, were announced in Rodney et al. (<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib165\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib165\">2015a</a>). Three of the other RELICS SNe are lensed, and we obtained follow-up <em>HST</em> imaging of them, using 20 orbits allocated to RELICS for this purpose (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt7\">7</a>). The most distant, dubbed \"Nebra,\" is a <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a02 candidate Type Ia lensed by A1763 (Rodney et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib166\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib166\">2016a</a>). If the redshift and type were confirmed, Nebra would be among the most distant SNe Ia known. The current record holder at <em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a02.22 is also lensed (Rubin et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib171\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib171\">2018</a>).</p><div tabindex=\"-1\" id=\"apjab412bt18\" class=\"boxout boxout-bdr-grey keyboard-focus-only\"><p><b>Table 18.</b>\u00a0\nRELICS Supernovae and <em>HST</em> Follow-up Imaging\n</p><table cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" data-toolbar-link=\"apjab412bt18\" data-toolbar-img=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt18_lr.gif\" data-toolbar-type=\"table\" data-toolbar-title=\"Table 18\"><colgroup><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col><col align=\"left\"></col></colgroup><thead>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Cluster</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Supernova<sup>a</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Abbreviation<sup>b</sup>\n</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">R.A. (J2000)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Decl. (J2000)</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Notes</th>\n</tr>\n</thead><tbody>\n<tr valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">rxc0949+17</td>\n<td valign=\"top\">\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">smacs0723-73</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">Yupana</td>\n<td colspan=\"1\" rowspan=\"1\" align=\"left\">lensed or cluster member</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody></table><p><small>\n<p><strong>Notes.</strong></p>\n<a name=\"apjab412bt18fna\" id=\"apjab412bt18fna\"></a><sup> a</sup>Each SN was named after a historical relic, with the exceptions of Eleanor and Alexander, named after Deputy PI Bradley's children, and William, named after PI Coe's newborn son.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt18fnb\" id=\"apjab412bt18fnb\"></a><sup> b</sup>Abbreviations include the last two digits of the year of appearance.\n<a name=\"apjab412bt18fnc\" id=\"apjab412bt18fnc\"></a><sup> c</sup>Discovered in pre-RELICS imaging based on difference comparison with RELICS imaging.\n</small></p><p class=\"franklin fs-16\">\n\t\t\tDownload table as:\u00a0\n            <span class=\"btn-multi-block\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-ascii\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt18_ascii.txt?doi=10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b\" target=\"_blank\">ASCII</a><a class=\"btn btn-primary wd-jnl-art-btn-typeset typeset-table-img\" href=\"/0004-637X/884/1/85/suppdata/apjab412bt18_lr.gif\" target=\"_blank\">Typeset image</a></span></p></div></div></div>\n<h2 class=\"header-anchor\" id=\"apjab412bs7\" name=\"apjab412bs7\">7.\u00a0Summary</h2><div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>With RELICS observations complete, the 34 most massive <em>Planck</em> clusters (<span xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"inline-eqn\"><span class=\"tex\"><span class=\"texImage\"><img src=\"https://static.iopscience.com/2.44.0/img/lazy-loading-placeholder.gif\" data-src=\"https://cdn.iopscience.com/images/0004-637X/884/1/85/Full/apjab412bieqn54.gif\" alt=\"${M}_{500}\\gt 8.8\\times {10}^{14}{M}_{\\odot }$\" align=\"top\"></img></span><script type=\"math/tex\">{M}_{500}\\gt 8.8\\times {10}^{14}{M}_{\\odot }</script></span></span>) now all have <em>HST</em> optical and near-infrared imaging, as well as <em>Spitzer</em> infrared imaging. Based on this imaging, we have discovered over 300 <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06\u201310 candidates, including the brightest galaxies known at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a06 (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib173\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib173\">2017</a>) and the most distant spatially resolved lensed arc known, SPT0615-JD at <em>z</em>\u00a0~\u00a010 (Salmon et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib174\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib174\">2018</a>). These are among the best and brightest targets for detailed follow-up study from the first billion years after the big bang. Follow-up observations of RELICS fields are currently being carried out with facilities including Keck, VLT, Subaru, Magellan, MMT, GMRT, and ALMA.</p><p>At lower redshifts, RELICS is studying compact, low-metallicity dwarf galaxies that are excellent analogs to high-redshift galaxies but can be studied in greater detail. We have also discovered 11 SNe (Table <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"tabref\" href=\"#apjab412bt18\">18</a>).</p><p>To date, we have published strong-lens modeling analyses of 14 RELICS clusters (Acebron et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib4\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib4\">2018</a>, <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib3\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib3\">2019</a>; Cerny et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib34\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib34\">2018</a>; Cibirka et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib37\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib37\">2018</a>; Paterno-Mahler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib138\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib138\">2018</a>; Mahler et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib109\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib109\">2019</a>). Many of the clusters modeled so far have proven to be comparable to the strongest lenses known. By combining our strong-lensing analyses of the cluster cores with weak-lensing analyses from ground-based imaging covering the full clusters out to their virial radii, we can derive robust mass profiles for these clusters. Our cluster mass measurements will help inform SZ mass scaling relations.</p><p>RELICS has proven once again that cluster lensing delivers distant galaxies more efficiently than blank-field observations. The efficiency gains are greatest for discoveries of relatively bright galaxies. We expect these gains to be even greater at higher redshifts. Our lens modeling analyses of RELICS clusters will identify which cluster lenses are truly among the best to use going forward to efficiently search for the first galaxies.</p><p>RELICS <em>HST</em> reduced images, catalogs, and lens models are available via MAST at doi:<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"dataset\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\" data-art-data-content-type=\"External repository\" data-toolbar-link=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\" data-toolbar-title=\"MAST dataset\" data-art-data-type=\"ext-rep-mast\" id=\"https://doi.org/10.17909/T9SP45\">10.17909/T9SP45</a>. RELICS <em>Spitzer</em> reduced images are available via IRSA.</p></div> <div class=\"article-text\" data-mobile-collapse=\"\"><p>We thank Lindsey Bleem for providing Magellan Megacam LDSS3 images of SPT0254-58 and AS295 prior to RELICS to inform our <em>HST</em> observations of these clusters. We thank Florian Pacaud and Matthias Klein for discussions regarding our AS295 <em>HST</em> pointings. We thank Dale Kocevski for an image of RXC 0142+44 obtained with the University of Hawaii 2.2 m telescope. And we thank Stella Seitz et al. for sharing their <em>HST</em> observations of PLCK G287+32 obtained during the same cycle.</p><p>We thank the STScI and SSC directors and time allocation committees for enabling these large observing programs. We are grateful to our <em>HST</em> program coordinator William Januszewski for implementing the RELICS <em>HST</em> observations. We thank Jennifer Mack for expert mentoring of our <em>HST</em> image reduction gurus RA and SO. And we thank Gabriel Brammer for providing an updated WFC3/IR hot pixel mask derived from science observations from GO 14114.</p><p>We are grateful to the University of Arizona for hosting our team meeting.</p><p>The RELICS Hubble Treasury Program (GO 14096) consists of observations obtained by the NASA/ESA <em>Hubble Space Telescope (HST). HST</em> is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. (AURA), under NASA contract NAS5-26555.</p><p>Data from the NASA/ESA <em>HST</em> presented in this paper were obtained from the Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes (MAST), operated by the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI). STScI is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc.\u00a0(AURA), under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. The <em>HST</em> Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) was developed under NASA contract NAS 5-32864.</p><p><em>Spitzer Space Telescope</em> data presented in this paper were obtained from the NASA/IPAC Infrared Science Archive (IRSA), operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology. <em>Spitzer</em> and IRSA are operated by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, California Institute of Technology, under contract with NASA.</p><p>We gratefully acknowledge support from JPL for the <em>Spitzer</em> analysis. M.B. and V.S. also acknowledge support by NASA through ADAP grant 80NSSC18K0945, NASA/<em>HST</em> through HST-GO-14096, HST-GO-13666, and two awards issued by <em>Spitzer</em>/JPL/Caltech associated with the SRELICS_DEEP and SRELICS programs.</p><p>Part of this work by W.D. was performed under the auspices of the U.S.\u00a0DOE by LLNL under contract DE-AC52-07NA27344. K.U. acknowledges support from the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan (grant MOST 106-2628-M-001-003-MY3) and from Academia Sinica (grant AS-IA-107-M01). O.G. is supported by an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Fellowship under award AST-1602595. S.A.R. was supported by NASA grant HST-GO-14208 from STScI, which is operated by Associated Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. (AURA), under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. A.M. acknowledges the financial support of the Brazilian funding agency FAPESP (Post-doc fellowship\u2014process No. 2014/11806-9). J.H. was supported by a VILLUM FONDEN Investigator grant (project No. 16599).</p><p>Finally, we thank our referee for detailed comments that helped us improve the manuscript.</p><p><em>Facilities:</em> <em>HST</em> (WFC3 - ,  ACS); <em>Spitzer</em> (IRAC); <em>Planck</em>; MAST; IRSA. - \n</p></div></div><!-- End article full text -->\n<!-- Start Footnotes -->\n\t<h2 id=\"footnotes\">Footnotes</h2>\n\t\t<div data-mobile-collapse=\"\">\n\t\t\t<ul class=\"clear-list wd-content-footnotes\">\n\t\t\t\t<li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjab412bfn1\" id=\"apjab412bfn1\">36\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p><em>Planck</em> PSZ2 catalogs are available and described at <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/Planck/release_2/catalogs/\">http://irsa.ipac.caltech.edu/data/Planck/release_2/catalogs/</a>\u00a0and\u00a0<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://wiki.cosmos.esa.int/planckpla2015/index.php/Catalogues\">https://wiki.cosmos.esa.int/planckpla2015/index.php/Catalogues</a>\n</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjab412bfn2\" id=\"apjab412bfn2\">37\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>\n<a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"webref\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://archive.stsci.edu/hst/search.php\">http://archive.stsci.edu/hst/search.php</a>\n</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjab412bfn3\" id=\"apjab412bfn3\">38\u00a0</div><div class=\"indices-content\"><p class=\"mb-0\"><p>The Frontier Fields cluster A370 has a lower <em>Planck</em> mass <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>\u00a0=\u00a07.7\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>14</sup><em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub> (though weak-lensing analysis yields a far greater <em>M</em><sub>500</sub>\u00a0=\u00a01.9\u00a0<b>&#x00d7;</b>\u00a010<sup>15</sup><em>M</em><sub>\u2299</sub>; Umetsu et al. <a xmlns:xlink=\"http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink\" class=\"cite\" href=\"#apjab412bbib201\" id=\"fnref-apjab412bbib201\">2011</a>). MACS J0416.1-2403 is PSZ2 G221.06-44.05, but the association was not initially made; without the redshift, no mass estimate was possible in the PSZ2 catalog. However, the relatively low <em>Planck</em> signal-to-noise ratio of 5.2 suggests a lower mass.</p></p></div></li><li class=\"indices-list\"><div class=\"indices-id\" name=\"apjab412bfn4\" Box 653, Beer-Sheva 84105, Israel), BY(School of Physics, University of Melbourne, VIC 3010, Australia; ARC Centre of Excellence for All Sky Astrophysics in 3 Dimensions (ASTRO 3D), VIC 2010, Australia), BZ(Space Telescope Science Institute, 3700 San Martin Drive, Baltimore, MD 21218, USA), CA(Leiden Observatory, Leiden University, NL-2300 RA Leiden, The Netherlands), CB(Department of Theoretical Physics, University of the Basque Country UPV/EHU, E-48080 Bilbao, Spain), CC(Cosmic Dawn Center (DAWN), Copenhagen, Denmark ; Niels Bohr Institute, University of Copenhagen, Lyngbyvej 2, DK-2100, Copenhagen, Denmark), CD(Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA), CE(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Kentucky, 505 Rose Street, Lexington, KY 40506, USA)"], "journal_name": "The Astrophysical Journal", "volume": "884", "publication_year": "2019/10/1", "start_page": "85", "keywords": ["dark ages", "reionization", "first stars", "dark matter", "galaxies: clusters: general", "galaxies: high-redshift", "gravitational lensing: strong", "supernovae: general", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies", "Astrophysics - Cosmology and Nongalactic Astrophysics"], "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019ApJ...884...85C", "abstract": "Large surveys of galaxy clusters with the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) and Spitzer, including the Cluster Lensing And Supernova survey with Hubble and the Frontier Fields, have demonstrated the power of strong gravitational lensing to efficiently deliver large samples of high-redshift galaxies. We extend this strategy through a wider, shallower survey named RELICS, the Reionization Lensing Cluster Survey, described here. Our 188-orbit Hubble Treasury Program observed 41 clusters at 0.182 \u2264 z \u2264 0.972 with Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) and WFC3/IR imaging spanning 0.4-1.7 \u03bcm. We selected 21 of the most massive clusters known based on Planck PSZ2 estimates and 20 additional clusters based on observed or inferred lensing strength. RELICS observed 46 WFC3/IR pointings (\u223c200 arcmin<SUP>2</SUP>) each with two orbits divided among four filters (F105W, F125W, F140W, and F160W) and ACS imaging as needed to achieve single-orbit depth in each of three filters (F435W, F606W, and F814W). As previously reported by Salmon et al., we discovered over 300 z \u223c 6-10 candidates, including the brightest z \u223c 6 candidates known, and the most distant spatially resolved lensed arc known at z \u223c 10. Spitzer IRAC imaging (945 hr awarded, plus 100 archival, spanning 3.0-5.0 \u03bcm) has crucially enabled us to distinguish z \u223c 10 candidates from z \u223c 2 interlopers. For each cluster, two HST observing epochs were staggered by about a month, enabling us to discover 11 supernovae, including 3 lensed supernovae, which we followed up with 20 orbits from our program. Reduced HST images, catalogs, and lens models are available on MAST, and reduced Spitzer images are available on IRSA.", "doi": "10.3847/1538-4357/ab412b", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1903.02002", "issn": "0004-637X", "number": "1"}, "Inspection status": "Incomplete"}
